{{Infobox adult biography | name = Henry Chesbrough | image = Henry Chesbrough at Open Innovation 2.0 Conference 2016 02.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1956 | birth_place = | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Yale University]]
[[Stanford Graduate School of Business]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]] | occupation = Professor and [[Author]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = [[Garwood Center for Corporate Innovation]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | agent = | known_for = [[Open Innovation]] | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | number_of_films = }} '''Henry William Chesbrough''' (born 1956) is an American organizational theorist, adjunct professor and the faculty director of the Garwood Center for Corporate Innovation at the [[Haas School of Business]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He is known for coining the term [[open innovation]].''[[The Guardian]]''. [https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2012/aug/15/crowdsourcing-global-health-research "Crowdsourcing reveals life-saving potential in global health research"]. August 15, 2012. Retrieved on May 30, 2013. == Biography == Chesbrough holds a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in [[Economics]] from [[Yale University]], an [[MBA]] from [[Stanford Graduate School of Business]], and a [[PhD]] from the [[Haas School of Business]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He taught at the [[Harvard Business School]] as an [[assistant professor]] and Class of 1961 Fellow from 1997 to 2003. He is currently an [[adjunct professor]] and the [[executive director|faculty director]] of the Garwood Center for Corporate Innovation at the [[Haas School of Business]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].''[[CBS MoneyWatch]]''. [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505125_162-31040215/berkeley-haas-henry-chesbrough-on-open-innovation/ "Berkeley-Haas' Henry Chesbrough on 'Open Innovation'"]. November 26, 2008. Retrieved on May 30, 2013. He acts as the chairman of the Open Innovation Center - Brazil. His first appearance in Brazil was in 2008, when he did a presentation in the Open Innovation Seminar 2008. He also acts as the chairman of board of advisors for Induct Software and appeared in [[Oslo]] on the 2011 Oslo Innovation Week == Publications == * {{cite book |date= 2003 |title= Open Innovation: The New Imperative for Creating and Profiting from Technology |publisher= HBS Press |first= Henry |last= Chesbrough |display-authors= 0 |isbn= 978-1422102831 }} * {{cite book |date= 2006 |title= Open Business Models: How to Thrive in the New Innovation Landscape |publisher= HBS Press |first= Henry |last= Chesbrough |display-authors= 0 |isbn= 978-1422104279}} * {{cite book |date= 2006 |title= Open Innovation: Researching a New Paradigm |publisher= Oxford |first= Henry |last= Chesbrough |display-authors= 0 |isbn= 978-0199226467}} * {{cite book |date= 2010 |title= Open Services Innovation: Rethinking Your Business to Grow and Compete in a New Era |publisher= Jossey-Bass |first= Henry |last= Chesbrough |display-authors= 0 |isbn= 978-0470905746 }} * {{cite book |date= 2014 |title= New Frontiers in Open Innovation |publisher= Oxford |first= Henry |last= Chesbrough |display-authors= 0 |isbn= 978-0199682461 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} * [http://www.haas.berkeley.edu/faculty/chesbrough.html Henry Chesbrough] at [[Haas School of Business]] * {{google scholar id |_HyypBAAAAAJ }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chesbrough, Henry}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Haas School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School faculty]] [[Category:Stanford Graduate School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]]

'''Hisham Mackie''' (born 1969<ref>[http://www.pacweb.org/Documents/annual-reviews-diamonds//SierraLeone_AR_2004-Eng.pdf Hisham Mackie: Sierra Leone’s Biggest Diamond Exporter], ''Diamond Industry Annual Review, Sierre Leone 2004'', p. 7; Partnership Africa Canada. Accessed July 10, 2010</ref>) is a [[Sierra Leone]]an [[businessman]]. He is by far the biggest diamond [[exporter]] from Sierra Leone, accounting for 51% of all official Sierra Leone diamond [[exports]]<ref name=Dixon2006a /><ref name=Dixon2006b /> Mackie runs H.M Diamond, a company which accounted for 40% of all diamond exports in 2005.<ref name=Massaquoi2006 />
==Biography== Hisham Mackie was born in Freetown, Sierra Leone in April, 6, 1969 to a [[Sierra Leonean-Lebanese]] family which has been in the diamond business since 1952. His father, a second generation Sierra Leonean-Lebanese, was among the first diamond dealers licensed by the Sierra Leone government during the early sixtees. Mackie did his [[secondary education]] at the famous and elite [[Bo School]] in [[Bo, Sierra Leone|Bo]] and graduated in 1986. After graduating from the Bo School, he went to [[England]] where he attended the [[University of London]] in 1987. Mackie joined the diamond business in 2002 as an export license holder.
== References == <references> <ref name=Dixon2006a>{{cite news|title=The World; Diamonds More Burden Than Asset for Sierra Leone; The prized gems fueled a 10-year civil war in the poor nation, which has seen most of the trading and exporting profits fall into foreign hands.|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author=Robyn Dixon|date=2006-05-25|pages=A.5}}</ref> <ref name=Dixon2006b>{{cite news|date=2006-03-13|title=Diamond labor yields little|author=Robyn Dixon|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com./html/nationworld/2002901035_diamonds31.html}}</ref> <ref name=Massaquoi2006>{{cite news|work=Concord Times|location=Freetown|title=Sierra Leone: $140 Million Exported: a Once-Struggling Sector Registers Net Gains|author=Mohamed Massaquoi|date=2006-01-12}}</ref> </references>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mackie, Hisham}} [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of London]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean businesspeople]] [[Category:Lebanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean people of Lebanese descent]]

revision.text:
[[File:John A. Creighton, 1854-1904 Nebraskans.png|thumb|right|230px|John A. Creighton, 1854-1904 Nebraskans]] [[Papal Count|Count]] '''John Andrew Creighton''' (October 15, 1831 – February 7, 1907)<ref name="Ireland and the Americas">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=agfvVQnBu9MC&pg=PA216&lpg=PA216&dq=john+creighton+1831+1907&source=bl&ots=B6YEpiYcC6&sig=Tz9n3TuTQZpPXuXeH_fVNZqLlTM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiay_X46P3YAhUKx2MKHc3fDKgQ6AEIJzAA#v=onepage&q=john%20creighton%201831%201907&f=false|chapter=Creighton, John Andrew (1831-1907)|title=Ireland and the Americas: Culture, Politics, and History : a Multidisciplinary Encyclopedia, Volume 2|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2008|pages=216–217|author=Milehich, Dennis|editors=Byrne, James P.; Coleman, Philip; and King, Jason|isbn=1851096140}}</ref> was a [[Founding figures of Omaha, Nebraska|pioneer]] businessman and philanthropist in [[Omaha]], [[Nebraska]] who founded [[Creighton University]]. The younger brother of [[Edward Creighton]], John was responsible for a variety of institutions throughout the city of Omaha, and was [[Papal Count#Roman count|ennobled]] by [[Pope Leo XIII]] in recognition of his contributions to Creighton University, the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Omaha|Catholic community in Omaha]], and the city of Omaha in general.<ref name="query.nytimes.com">[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1907/02/08/106739348.pdf "Count John A. Creighton Dead: Nebraskan Who Founded Colleges Was Enobled by the Pope,"] ''New York Times.'' February 8, 1907. Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref><ref name="books.google.com">''[https://books.google.com/books?id=WIFFAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=%22john+a+creighton%22+%22creighton+university%22&source=web&ots=EaQIhmBS4W&sig=v0BPcfRAa4paoBqBOAFauONUPWQ#PPA43,M1 Creighton: Biographical Sketches of Edward Creighton and John A. Creighton.]'' p 42.</ref>
==Biography== Born in [[Licking County, Ohio]], Creighton's first job was working for his brother [[Edward Creighton|Edward]], installing a [[telegraph]] line from [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]] to [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]]. In 1852 he enrolled in St. Joseph's Dominican School near [[Somerset, Ohio]]. In 1856 he came to Omaha as a clerk with a local merchant, and in 1860 he took two jobs moving cattle and freight from Omaha to [[Denver, Colorado]]. Around that same period Edward accepted a contract installing {{convert|700|mi|km}} of the [[Pacific Telegraph]], the [[First Transcontinental Telegraph]] in the United States. John was hired as the superintendent of the construction. In the early 1860s Creighton traveled to [[Montana]] to mine gold, eventually installing a telegraph line from [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] to [[Helena, Montana]].<ref name="query.nytimes.com"/><ref name="South Omaha">(1880) [http://www.rootsweb.com/~neresour/OLLibrary/Omaha_book/omaha042.htm "South Omaha"], ''Omaha Illustrated.'' D.C. Dunbar and Company. p. 114. Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref>
During Creighton's life in Montana he is credited with helping rid the state of the [[outlaw|desperados]] who made it inhospitable towards settlement. In 1865 after he was assaulted and his leg was broken, a local newspaper wrote, "We believe that the only way to kill John Creighton would be to cut his head off and then carry away the body." During this same period of time Creighton was named a "[[Colonel]]" by Montana's acting Governor General [[Thomas Francis Meagher]].<ref name="books.google.com"/>
In 1868 John Creighton returned to Omaha permanently,<ref name="query.nytimes.com"/> where he established a grocery business in [[Jobber's Canyon]]. In 1868 John married [[Sarah Emily Wareham]], the sister of [[Mary Lucretia Creighton]], who was married to John's brother Edward. When Edward died suddenly in 1874, his wife Mary became committed to his notion of creating a free college in Nebraska. She died in 1876, leaving a considerable amount of money along with strict instructions for the foundation of the college in her husband's honor. John, his cousin James, and [[Herman Kountze]], a banker and family friend, were the executors of Edwards will. Acting in that capacity they purchased the present site of the University and proceeded to erect what is now called Creighton Hall.<ref>Morton, J. and Watkins, A. (1918) [http://www.rootsweb.com/~neresour/OLLibrary/MWHNE/mwhne492.htm "Creighton University"], ''History of Nebraska from the Earliest Explorations of the Trans-Mississippi Region''. Lincoln, NE: Western Publishing and Engraving Company. p. 188. Retrieved 7/15/07.</ref>
John's wife Sarah died September 3, 1888; before her death she bequeathed a business block near [[Downtown Omaha]] to the yet-to-be-established Creighton College. By the early 1890s he was attributed to holding, "more of the valuable real estate of the city [of Omaha] than any other individual."<ref>[http://www.rootsweb.com/~neresour/OLLibrary/Omaha_book/omaha042.htm "South Omaha"], ''Omaha Illustrated.'' Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref> He owned a [[South Omaha Terminal Railway|railroad company]], was a large stockholder in the [[Omaha Cable Tramway Company]], heavily interested in the [[South Omaha]] syndicate responsible for building up much of that area, and was Vice-President of the [[First National of Nebraska|First National Bank of Omaha]].<ref name="South Omaha"/>
In 1884 Creighton was a delegate to the Democratic National Convention at [[Chicago]] where [[Grover Cleveland]] was nominated for [[President of the United States]].<ref name="South Omaha"/>
===Philanthropy=== From its founding in 1878 to the time of his death in 1907 Creighton was said to have donated at least $2,000,000 to Creighton University.<ref>Federal Writers' Project Staff (1939) ''Nebraska: A guide to the Cornhusker state.'' Federal Writers' Project of the Works Progress Administration for the State of Nebraska. p. 242.</ref> In 1888 Creighton financed the [[Creighton University Observatory]], and in 1898 he gave money towards a medical school, which was named in his honor. In 1904 he created the Edward Creighton Institute.<ref name="query.nytimes.com"/> Creighton is also credited with establishing Omaha's [[Saint Joseph Hopital at Creighton University Medical Center|St. Joseph's Hospital]] and bringing the first monastery of the [[Poor Clares]] in the country to the city.<ref>[https://people.creighton.edu/~bjk79676/JACreighton.htm "John A. Creighton"], Creighton University. Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref> He paid for almost the entire cost of [[St. John's Parish (Omaha, Nebraska)|St. John's Parish]] at Creighton, where the cornerstone was laid in 1888.<ref>[http://www2.creighton.edu/ministry/stjohns/history/index.php "The cornerstone laying must have been an impressive event..."] St. John's Parish. Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref>
===Recognition=== Today [[Creighton University]] in Omaha is viewed as being named in honor of the entire Creighton family, particularly John and his brother Edward, as well as their wives Sara and Emily.<ref>The town of [[Creighton, Nebraska]] was also named in his honor. [http://www.nebraskahistory.org/publish/markers/texts/creighton_university.htm "Creighton University"], Nebraska State Historical Society. Retrieved 1/23/08.</ref> He was named a [[Knight of St. Gregory]] on January 15, 1895 by [[Pope Leo XIII]],<ref>[http://press.creighton.edu/111403/cu1252.html "Creighton's history by the numbers"], ''Creightonian Online.'' Retrieved 1/23/08.</ref> and in 1898 was titled a [[Count]] by the same.<ref name="query.nytimes.com"/> In 1900 Creighton received the [[Laetare Medal]] from the [[University of Notre Dame]].<ref>Dowling, MP [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04480a.htm "Creighton University"], ''Catholic Encyclopedia. Retrieved 1/22/08.</ref> Omaha's [[John A. Creighton Boulevard]] was named after him immediately after his death in 1907,<ref>[http://www.omahahistory.org/Education_StreetNames3.htm "Street names"], Douglas County Historical Society. Retrieved 1/23/08.</ref> as is the existent "John A. Creighton University Professorship" at Creighton University.
The [[Orpheum Theater (Omaha)|Creighton Orpheum Theater]] in [[Downtown Omaha]] was named in honor of John after he donated a significant portion of its construction costs.<ref>[http://www.operaomaha.org/tickets/orpheum/index.asp "Venue information"], Opera Omaha. Retrieved 1/23/08.</ref>
==See also== * [[History of Omaha]] * [[Founding figures of Omaha, Nebraska]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Byrne, James Patrick, et al. eds. Ireland and the Americas: culture, politics, and history: a multidisciplinary encyclopedia (2008) 1:215-17 * Mullens, Patrick Aloysius. ''Creighton: Biographical Sketches of Edward Creighton, John A. Creighton, Mary Lucretia Creighton, Sarah Emily Creighton'' (1901)
==External links== * [http://cudigital.cdmhost.com/cdm4/browse.php?&CISOSTART=1,61 Photos] from Creighton's 1907 funeral * [http://www.nps.gov/gosp/research/creighton.htm National Park Service: Edward Creighton] * {{YouTube|K_dAFlR7KkM|The Creightons: Building a Dream}} * {{YouTube|7CewoSycSas|The Creightons: Edward and the Creightons}} * {{YouTube|BkacseCDVzk|Working at NET Television}} * {{YouTube|Vak9SVpxLY8|The Creightons: The Making of The Creightons}} * {{YouTube|26ZMmH7tDHw|The Creightons: The Spirit of Creighton}} * {{YouTube|4jDCHuiVkqM|The Creightons: The Children of Creighton}}
{{North Omaha}} {{Omaha Railroads}} {{Omaha Stockyards}} {{Creighton University}}

{{Infobox person | name = John Dandridge Jr. | image = Col. John Dandridge Jr.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Col. John Dandridge Jr. | birth_name = John Dandridge Jr. | birth_date = 13/14 July 1700 | birth_place = [[England]] | death_date = 31 August 1756 | death_place = [[Fredericksburg, Virginia|Fredericksburg]], [[Colony of Virginia]], [[British America]] | death_cause = | resting_place = Interred at [[St. George's Episcopal Church (Fredericksburg, Virginia)|St. George's Episcopal Church]] | residence = | nationality = [[English people|English]] | citizenship = | education = | occupation = [[Colonel]], [[Planter (American South)|Planter]], [[Politician]], [[Clerk]] | employer = | known_for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | spouse = [[Frances Jones (colonist)|Frances Jones]] | partner = | children = [[Martha Washington]]
John Dandridge III
William Dandridge III
[[Bartholomew Dandridge]]
Anne Dandridge
Frances Dandridge
Elizabeth Dandridge
Mary Dandridge | parents = Col. John Dandridge Sr.
Bridget Dugdale | relations = Capt. William Dandridge I (grandfather)
Col. Bartholomew Dandridge I (great-grandfather) | website = | signature = | signature_alt = }} [[File:Coat of Arms of William Dandridge.svg|thumb|Coat of Arms of Col. John Dandridge Jr.]] '''Col. John Dandridge Jr.''' of [[Chestnut Grove (plantation)|Chestnut Grove]][http://www.vahistorical.org/dynasties/johndandridge.htm Virginia Historical web site article on John Dandridge] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926222227/http://www.vahistorical.org/dynasties/johndandridge.htm |date=2007-09-26 }} (13/14 July 1700 – 31 August 1756) was a distinguished [[colonel]], planter, politician, and Clerk of the Courts of [[New Kent County, Virginia|New Kent County]], [[Virginia]] from 1730 to 1756.{{cite web | url=http://auden.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/auden/individual.php?pid=I5663&ged=auden-bicknell.ged | title= Col. John Dandridge (I5663) | date= | accessdate=2009-02-14 | publisher=Stanford University | author=W. H. Auden}} Dandridge is best known as the father of the first [[First Lady of the United States]] [[Martha Washington]], wife of [[George Washington]], the first president of the [[United States]].* Tyler, Lyon Gardiner, ed. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UCgSAAAAYAAJ ''Encyclopedia of Virginia biography"]. Volume 1. New York: Lewis Historical Publishing Company, 1915. {{OCLC|2576742}}. Retrieved July 15, 2011. pp. 220–221. == Early life == Born on 13 July 1700 in [[England]], Dandridge was the youngest son of Col. John Dandridge Sr. ([[Oxford]], [[Oxfordshire]], April 29, 1655 - Oxford, Oxfordshire, 1731), and wife (m. St. Mary Magdalen, London, 1676) Bridget Dugdale (Oxford, Oxfordshire, c. 1656 - 1731); paternal grandson of Capt. William Dandridge I ([[Drayton St. Leonard]], Oxfordshire, England, 30 January 1612 - [[Dorchester Abbey]], Dorchester On [[Thames]], England, July 1693) and wife; and great-grandson of Col. Bartholomew Dandridge I (England, c. 1580 - Drayton St. Leonard, Oxfordshire, England, 21 September 1638) and wife (m. England, 10 May 1604) Agnes Wilder (c. 1585 - c. 1650). He immigrated to [[Virginia]] at the age of 14 in 1715. == Marriage and children == Dandridge married [[Frances Jones (colonist)|Frances Orlando Jones]], daughter of Orlando Jones and Martha Macon Jones West, on 22 July 1730 in [[New Kent County, Virginia|New Kent County]], Virginia. John and Frances had eight children: *[[Martha Washington|Martha Dandridge Custis Washington]] (1731–1802) *John Dandridge III (1733–1749) *William Dandridge III (1734–1776) *[[Bartholomew Dandridge|Bartholomew Dandridge II]] (1737–1785) *Anna Marie "Fanny" Dandridge Bassett (1739–1777) *Frances Dandridge (1744–1757) *Elizabeth Dandridge Aylett Henley (1749–1800) *Mary Dandridge (1725–1777) == Career and residences == Upon their marriage in 1730, John and Frances moved to their new home on the banks of the [[Pamunkey River]] in New Kent County, Virginia, [[Chestnut Grove (plantation)|Chestnut Grove]]. John became [[Supreme Court of Virginia|Clerk of Courts]] in New Kent County and kept that position for the next 26 years. He was also [[vestryman]] and [[churchwarden]] for [[St. Peter's Church (New Kent, Virginia)|St. Peter's Church]]. John was a prominent planter, and a colonel in his military district. John's older brother, William Dandridge II (1689–1743), lived on the opposite bank of the river with his wife [[Unity West]] Dandridge, daughter of [[Nathaniel West (captain)|Nathaniel West]] and wife Martha Woodard Macon, at their estate, [[Elsing Green]], in [[King William County, Virginia|King William County]]. Chestnut Grove burned down in 1926, but its former site was only four miles from the location of the current county court house for New Kent. Along with Chestnut Grove in New Kent, John and Frances also owned a house in [[Colonial Williamsburg|Williamsburg]] and visited there frequently. == Later life == Dandridge died on 31 August 1756 at the age of 56 in [[Fredericksburg, Virginia|Fredericksburg]], Virginia. Dandridge is interred at [[St. George's Episcopal Church (Fredericksburg, Virginia)|St. George's Episcopal Church]] burial ground in Fredericksburg.{{cite web | url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=11599 | title=John Dandridge | date=August 9, 2000 | accessdate=2009-02-14 | publisher=[[Find A Grave]] | author=}} == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == * Tyler, Lyon Gardiner, ed. [https://books.google.com/books?id=UCgSAAAAYAAJ ''Encyclopedia of Virginia biography"]. Volume 1. New York: Lewis Historical Publishing Company, 1915. {{OCLC|2576742}}. Retrieved July 15, 2011. {{DEFAULTSORT:Dandridge, John}} [[Category:1700 births]] [[Category:1756 deaths]] [[Category:Dandridge family of Virginia]] [[Category:People from New Kent County, Virginia]] [[Category:British North American Anglicans]] [[Category:American planters]] [[Category:British emigrants to the Thirteen Colonies]] [[Category:County clerks in Virginia]]

{{Infobox peer |name = The Lord Fairfax of Cameron |image = |caption = |birth_date = September 18, 1830 |birth_place = [[Vaucluse (plantation)|Vaucluse]], [[Virginia]] |death_date = September 25, 1900 (aged 70) |death_place = [[Prince George's County, Maryland]] |title = 11th Lord Fairfax of Cameron |tenure = 1869-1900 |other_names = |known_for = |nationality = American |locality = |parents = Albert Fairfax
Caroline Eliza Snowden |children = [[Albert Fairfax, 12th Lord Fairfax of Cameron|Albert Fairfax]] }} '''John Contee Fairfax, 11th Lord Fairfax''', (September 18, 1830 – September 25, 1900) was an American born Scottish [[Peerage|peer]]. ==Early life== John Contee Fairfax was born at [[Vaucluse (plantation)|Vaucluse]], [[Virginia]], the second son of Albert Fairfax (April 15, 1802 – May 9, 1835) and Caroline Eliza Snowden (April 21, 1812 – December 28, 1899), who were married on April 7, 1828. His elder brother was [[Charles S. Fairfax|Charles S. Fairfax, 10th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]].{{cite book |last= du Bellet |first= Louise Pecquet |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= 1907 |publisher= Bell Company |day= |title= Some Prominent Virginian Families |journal= |volume= |issue= |pages= |id= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=tyQSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA176 |accessdate= |quote= }} ==Personal life== He married Mary Kirby, daughter of Col. Edward Kirby, in 1857. They had the following children: *Caroline Snowden Fairfax *Josephine Fairfax, who married Tunstall Smith *[[Albert Fairfax, 12th Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] (1870-1939), who married Maude Wishart. He died at age 70 in his country home Northampton, in [[Prince George's County, Maryland]]. At the time of his death he was the only [[Peerage|British peer]] with American citizenship.{{cite journal|last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= September 30, 1900 |publisher= The New York Times Company |day= |title= Titled American Dead; Lord Fairfax and Baron Cameron Passes Away in Maryland. Descendant of Great Scottish Family That Figures in English History -- New Peer Lived in This City. |journal= The New York Times |volume= |issue= |pages= |id= |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1900/09/30/archives/titled-american-dead-lord-fairfax-and-baron-cameron-passes-away-in.html |accessdate= |quote= }} ==See also== *[[Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{S-start}} {{s-reg|sct}} {{succession box | title = [[Lord Fairfax of Cameron]] | before = [[Charles S. Fairfax]] | after = [[Albert Fairfax, 12th Lord Fairfax of Cameron|Albert Fairfax]] | years = 1869–1900}} {{S-end}} {{Fairfax family}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fairfax, John, 11 Lord Fairfax of Cameron}} [[Category:1830 births]] [[Category:1900 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American Episcopalians]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Fairfax family|John]] [[Category:Lords of Parliament]] [[Category:People from Fairfax County, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Prince George's County, Maryland]] {{Lord-of-Parliament-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder |image = Julia Tyler.jpg |caption = Tyler's White House Portrait (September 1844) |office = [[First Lady of the United States]] |president = [[John Tyler]] |term_start = June 26, 1844 |term_end = March 4, 1845 |term_label = In role |predecessor = [[Priscilla Cooper Tyler|Priscilla Tyler]] {{small|(Acting)}} |successor = [[Sarah Childress Polk|Sarah Polk]] |birth_name=Julia Gardiner |birth_date = {{birth date|1820|5|4}} |birth_place = [[Gardiner's Island]], New York, US |death_date = {{death date and age|1889|7|10|1820|5|4}} |death_place = [[Richmond, Virginia]], US |restingplace= [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]]
Richmond, Virginia, US |spouse = {{marriage|[[John Tyler]]|1844|1862|reason=died}} |children = 7, including [[David Gardiner Tyler]], [[John Alexander Tyler]] and [[Lyon Gardiner Tyler]] |parents = [[David Gardiner (politician)|David Gardiner]]
Juliana MacLachlan |religion = [[Presbyterianism]] {{small|(Before 1872)}}
[[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] {{small|(1872–1889)}} |nationality = American |signature = Julia Tyler Signature.svg }} '''Julia Gardiner Tyler''' (May 4, 1820 – July 10, 1889{{Britannica|611489|Julia Tyler}}) was the second wife of [[John Tyler]], who was the tenth [[President of the United States]], and served as the [[First Lady of the United States]] from June 26, 1844, to March 4, 1845. ==Early life== Julia Gardiner Tyler was born in 1820 on [[New York (state)|New York]]'s [[Gardiner's Island]], one of the largest privately owned islands in the United States. She was the daughter of [[David Gardiner (politician)|David Gardiner]], a landowner and [[New York State Senate|New York State Senator]] (1824 to 1828), and Juliana MacLachlan Gardiner. Her ancestry was part [[Dutch people|Dutch]], part [[Scottish people|Scottish]] and part [[English people|English]].[http://www.firstladies.org/biographies/firstladies.aspx?biography=11 First Ladies] She was raised in the town of [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton]] and the small [[Administrative divisions of New York|hamlet]] of [[Bay Shore]], and educated at the Chegary Institute in New York. In 1839, she shocked [[Upper class|polite society]] by appearing, posed with an unidentified man and identified as "The Rose of Long Island", in a newspaper advertisement for a [[middle-class]] [[department store]]. Her family took her to Europe to avoid further publicity and allow her notoriety to subside. They first left for London, arriving on October 29, 1840. They visited England, France, Italy, Switzerland, Germany, Holland, Belgium, Ireland and Scotland before returning to New York in September 1841. ===Courtship with President Tyler=== On January 20, 1842, the 21-year-old Julia was introduced to President [[John Tyler]] at a [[White House]] reception. After the death of his first wife, [[Letitia Christian Tyler]], on September 10, 1842, Tyler made it clear that he wished to get involved with Julia. Initially the high-spirited and independent-minded northern beauty felt little attraction to the grave, reserved Virginia gentleman, who was thirty years her senior. He first proposed to her on February 22, 1843, when she was 22, at a White House Masquerade Ball. She hated that and hated later proposals he made. The increased time spent together prompted public speculation about their relationship. Julia, her sister Margaret, and her father joined a Presidential excursion on the new steam frigate [[USS Princeton (1843)|''Princeton'']]. During this excursion, her father, David Gardiner, along with a number of others, lost his life in the explosion of a huge naval gun called the ''Peacemaker''. Julia was devastated by the death of her adored father. She spoke often in later years of how the President's quiet strength sustained her during this difficult time. Tyler comforted Julia in her grief and won her consent to a secret engagement, proposing in 1844 at the George Washington Ball. ==First Lady of the United States== After a wedding trip to Philadelphia, a White House reception, and a stay at [[Sherwood Forest Plantation|Sherwood Forest]], an estate the president had recently acquired for his retirement, the newlyweds returned to Washington.{{cite news|last1=Rattiner|first1=Dan|title=Julia Gardiner, John Tyler, the White House and the Princeton|url=http://www.danspapers.com/2013/02/the-greatest-love-julia-gardiner-john-tyler-the-white-house-and-the-princeton/|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=Dans Papers|date=February 21, 2013|language=en}} Although her husband was often visibly fatigued, his youthful wife thoroughly enjoyed the duties of First Lady. The anthem "[[Hail to the Chief]]" had been played at a number of events associated with the arrival or presence of the President of the United States before Julia Tyler became First Lady, but she ordered its regular use to announce the arrival of the President. It became established practice when her successor, [[Sarah Childress Polk]] did likewise.{{cite news | work = New York Times | accessdate = March 22, 2017 | title = 'Hail to the Chief': The Musical Strains of Presidential Power | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/us/presidential-song-hail-to-the-chief.html | date = January 20, 2017 | first = Christine | last = Hauser}} In the last month of the Tyler administration, she hosted a grand White House ball for 3,000 guests.{{cite web|title=Julia Tyler|url=https://us-first-ladies.insidegov.com/l/46/Julia-Tyler|website=us-first-ladies.insidegov.com|accessdate=May 2, 2017|language=en-us}} ===Later life=== [[Image:Sherwood Forest-1961.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Sherwood Forest Plantation]] in [[Charles City County, Virginia]], in which she and [[John Tyler]] lived after leaving the [[White House]].]] The Tylers retired to [[Sherwood Forest Plantation|Sherwood Forest]], where they lived tranquilly until the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]. Although a northerner by birth, Mrs. Tyler soon grew accustomed to the leisurely routines of daily life as the wife of a wealthy plantation owner. Julia wrote a defense of slavery titled "''The Women of England vs. the Women of America''", in response to the "''Stafford House Address''" petition against slavery which the [[Harriet Sutherland-Leveson-Gower, Duchess of Sutherland|Duchess of Sutherland]] had helped to organize.{{cite book|author=Jean Fagan Yellin|title=Harriet Jacobs: A Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5TiUG7lUrBAC&pg=PA122|date=January 26, 2005|publisher=Basic Civitas Books|isbn=978-0-465-09289-5|pages=122–}}{{cite book|author=Julia Sun-Joo Lee|title=The American Slave Narrative and the Victorian Novel|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yKmDpXlxtIcC&pg=PA79|date=April 9, 2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-974528-9|pages=79–}}{{cite news|title=Mrs. Julia G. Tyler to the Duchess of Sutherland and others.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1853/02/05/archives/mrs-julia-g-tyler-to-the-duchess-of-sutherland-and-others.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 5, 1853}}{{cite news|title=ENGLAND.; Mrs. Tyler's Letter.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1853/03/02/archives/england-mrs-tylers-letter.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 2, 1853}} In response to Julia Tyler's essay, [[Harriet Jacobs]], a former slave and later abolitionist orator and writer, authored her first published work, a letter to the ''New York Tribune'' in 1853.{{cite book|author=Raja Sharma|title=Ready Reference Treatise: Incidents in the Life of a Slave Girl|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O8X1AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT12|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=978-1-300-30601-6|pages=12–}}{{cite book|author1=Kathryn Kish Sklar|author2=James Brewer Stewart|title=Women's Rights and Transatlantic Antislavery in the Era of Emancipation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQVHWXADuRYC&pg=PA165|year=2007|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0-300-13786-9|pages=165–}} After her husband's death in 1862,{{cite news|title=DEATH OF EX-PRESIDENT TYLER.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1862/01/22/news/death-of-ex-president-tyler.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 22, 1862}} she lost her 60 slaves and 1100 acres of land due to military events. Julia moved north to [[Staten Island]] with several of her children, although family relations were so strained that her brother David Gardiner refused to travel to Virginia to escort her to New York and eventually moved out of his mother's house, where Julia had settled. Her home there was almost burned down by enraged Union veterans when it was discovered that she was flying a Confederate flag on the property. She resided at the [[Gardiner-Tyler House]] from 1868 to 1874.{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=7771|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Gardiner-Tyler House|date=September 1984|accessdate=December 6, 2010|author=Merrill Hesch|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017170750/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=7771|archivedate=October 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{efn|The house was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1984.{{NRISref|2009a}}}} In 1865, her brother David sued to prevent her from inheriting the bulk of their mother's estate valued at $180,000, charging that Julia Tyler had exerted "undue influences" on their mother to execute a will despite her "mental incapacity".{{cite news|title=LAW REPORTS.; Court Calendar THIS DAY. The Gardiner-Tyler Will Case Important Opinion by the Surrogate of Richmond County The Widow of Ex President Tyler Not Entitled to Any Portion of the Gardiner Estate Undue Influences Brought to Bear on the Testatrix, &c.SURROGATE'S COURT RICHMOND COUNTY. Court of Special Sessions. Before Justices Kelly and Dowling. A CASE OF SHOPLIFTING. Criminal Business. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before Judge Russel. Decisions. SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS SEPT. 7. By Justice Ingraham.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1865/09/08/news/law-reports-court-calendar-this-day-gardiner-tyler-will-case-important-opinion.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 8, 1865}} The court supported his claim on August 25 and refused to accept the will.{{cite news | work = New York Times| accessdate = February 20, 2017 | date = September 8, 1865 | title = The Gardiner-Tyler Will Case, Important Opinion by the Surrogate of Richmond County, The Widow of ExPresident Tyler Not Entitled to Any Portion of the Gardiner Estate, Undue Influences Brought to Bear on the Testatrix, &c. | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1865/09/08/news/law-reports-court-calendar-this-day-gardiner-tyler-will-case-important-opinion.html?pagewanted=3 }} After two appeals, David Gardiner won the case in 1867.{{cite news|title=THE GARDINER-TYLER WILL.; The ease Finally Terminated-Important Opinion of the Court of Appeals--An Interesting Family HistoryJudgment of the Supreme Court at General Term Reversed, and the Decree of the Surrogate, Rejecting the sill, Affirmed--Motion for Re-Argument Denied.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1867/01/27/archives/the-gardinertyler-will-the-ease-finally-terminatedimportant-opinion.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 27, 1867}} David then asked the courts to partition the estate as if no will existed. Julia asked for a jury trial on the issue, and the jury declined to consider the contested will as an argument in her favor. The ''New York Times'' thought Julia was treated unfairly and that the dispute could be traced to "the political antagonisms of the rebellion, which have divide many a household besides that of Mrs. Gardiner".{{cite news|title=The Gardiner Will Case; A Decision in Equity|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1867/05/01/79711556.pdf |accessdate=February 20, 2017|work=New York Times|date=May 1, 1867}} {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | video1 =[http://firstladies.c-span.org/FirstLady/10/Anna-Harrison.aspx America's First Ladies, Anna Harrison, Letitia Tyler & Julia Tyler], 2013, [[C-SPAN]]{{cite web | title =America's First Ladies, Anna Harrison, Letitia Tyler & Julia Tyler | work =| publisher =[[C-SPAN]] | date =2013| url =http://firstladies.c-span.org/FirstLady/10/Anna-Harrison.aspx | accessdate =April 24, 2013}}}} She converted to [[Roman Catholicism]] and was re-baptized in May 1872.{{cite book|title=Virginia's Civil War| pages= 237–8 |first=Theodore C. | last=Delaney| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Ma-XQ2KqkyIC&pg=PA238&| date=2005 | publisher=University of Virginia Press |chapter=Surviving Defeat: The Trials of 'Mrs. Ex-President Tyler'|editor1-first=Peter|editor1-last=Wallenstein|editor2-first=Bertram|editor2-last=Wyatt-Brown}} The depression that followed the [[Panic of 1873]] depleted her finances. She returned to Virginia to live with the aid of her grown children.{{when|date=February 2017}} She lobbied Congress for a pension and was granted a monthly allowance in 1880. Following the assassination of President [[James Garfield]] in 1881, Congress granted an annual pension of $5000 to widows of former presidents.{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mlitLOFgYgYC&pg=PA14& |title= The Presidents' Wives: Reassessing the Office of First Lady | page= 14| first=Robert F. |last=Watson| publisher= Lynne Rienner Publishers |date=2000| location=Boulder, Colorado}} ==Personal life== Because of the circumstances surrounding her father's death, Julia and John agreed to marry with a minimum of celebration. On June 26, 1844, the President slipped into [[New York City]], where the nuptials were performed by the Right Reverend [[Benjamin Treadwell Onderdonk]], fourth bishop of the [[Episcopal Diocese of New York]], at the [[Church of the Ascension (New York)|Church of the Ascension]], not too far from the Gardiner's residence on [[Colonnade Row|LaGrange Terrace]]. President Tyler was 54 years old, while Julia was just 24. Tyler's oldest daughter, Mary, was 5 years older than her father's new wife.{{cite inside}}, pp.84-85 The marriage made Julia the first First Lady to marry a President who was already in office at the time of the wedding.[http://www.firstladies.org/biographies/firstladies.aspx?biography=11 Julia Gardiner Tyler-National First Ladies Library] The bride's sister, Margaret, and brother, Alexander, were bridesmaid and best man. Only the President's son, John Tyler III, represented the groom's family. Tyler was so concerned about maintaining secrecy that he did not confide his plans to the rest of his children. Although his sons readily accepted the sudden union, the Tyler daughters were shocked and hurt. The news was then broken to the American people, who greeted it with keen interest, much publicity, and some criticism about the couple's 30-year difference in age.{{cite web|title=Julia Tyler|url=https://www.whitehousehistory.org/bios/julia-tyler|website=whitehousehistory.org|publisher=[[White House Historical Association]]|accessdate=May 2, 2017|language=en}} It was awkward for the eldest Tyler daughter, Mary, to adjust to a new [[stepmother]] five years younger than herself. One daughter, Letitia, never made peace with her stepmother. Between 1846 and 1860, Julia and John had seven children together: * [[David Gardiner Tyler]] (1846–1927), a lawyer and public official.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=JUDGE TYLER, 81, SON OF EX-PRESIDENT, DEAD; Former Congressman Dies in Late Father's Home, Sherwood Forest -- Fought With Confederates.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1927/09/06/archives/judge-tyler-81-son-of-expresident-dead-former-congressman-dies-in.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 6, 1927}} * [[John Alexander Tyler|John "Alex" Alexander Tyler]] (1848–1883), an engineer who, like his older brother, dropped out of Washington College to join the [[Confederate army]] and, after the war, resumed his studies in Germany. There he joined the Saxon Army during the [[Franco-Prussian War]] and took part in the occupation of France in 1871. For his service he was decorated by the Prussian government. He became a mining engineer and, returning to the United States, was appointed U.S. surveyor of the Interior Department in 1879. While working in that capacity in New Mexico, he drank contaminated water and died at 35.{{cite book |last1=Todd |first1=Charles Burr |authorlink1=Charles Burr Todd |editor1-first=Henry Reed |editor1-last=Stiles |editor1-link=Henry Reed Stiles |title=In olde New York; sketches of old times and places in both the state and the city |url=https://archive.org/stream/inoldenewyorkske00toddch#page/174/mode/2up |accessdate=February 25, 2012 |type= |edition= |series=The Grafton historical series |year=1907 |publisher=The Grafton press |location=New York, NY |oclc=3985699 |pages=174–175 }} * Julia Gardiner Tyler (1849–1871), who married William H. Spencer, a debt-ridden farmer of [[York, New York|Piffard, New York]], in 1869. She died from the effects of childbirth at age 22 at the Spencer home, [[Westerly (Piffard, New York)|Westerly]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=3779|title=Register of Historic Places Registration: Westerly |date=July 1974|accessdate=September 1, 2009 |author=Cornelia E. Brooke|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]}} * Lachlan Gardiner Tyler (1851–1902), a doctor who practiced medicine in [[Jersey City, New Jersey]], and in 1879 became a surgeon in the U.S. Navy. From 1887, he practiced in [[Elkhorn, West Virginia]].{{cite book|last1=Columbia|first1=Medical Society of the District of|title=History of the Medical Society of the District of Columbia: 1817-1909|date=1909|publisher=The Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=secRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA311&lpg=PA311&dq=Lachlan+Tyler&source=bl&ots=osI5S0g6zU&sig=7cmVWU1bTeD-ZtaD1N5e1H_GPyk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwicyMHmsdHTAhUj7IMKHXUVCuA4ChDoAQhHMAg#v=onepage&q=Lachlan%20Tyler&f=false|accessdate=May 2, 2017|language=en}} * [[Lyon Gardiner Tyler]] (1853–1935), an educator.{{cite news|title=DR. LYON G. TYLER MARRIES.; Son of Tenth President of United States Weds Miss Ruff in.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/09/14/archives/dr-lyon-g-tyler-marries-son-of-tenth-president-of-united-states.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 14, 1923}}{{cite news|title=JOHN TYLER'S SON.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1932/02/18/archives/john-tylers-son.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 18, 1932}}{{cite news|title=DR. LYON TYLER, 82, DEAD IN RICHMOND Former Head of William and Mary College Was Son of Nation's 10th President {{!}} WELL KNOWN AS AUTHOR {{!}} Wrote Many Volumes on History of Virginia - Was Elected to State Legislature in 1887.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/02/13/archives/dr-lyon-tyler-82-dead-in-richoiond-former-head-of-williaj-and-mar.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 13, 1935}} * Robert "Fitz" Fitzwalter Tyler (1856–1927), a farmer of [[Hanover County, Virginia]].{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=ROBERT FITZWALTER TYLER; Youngest Son of Tenth President of United States Dies at 70.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1927/12/31/archives/robert-fitzwalter-tyler-youngest-son-of-tenth-president-of-united.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 31, 1927}} * Pearl Tyler (1860–1947), who at the age of 12 converted to Roman Catholicism along with her mother.{{cite news|title=MRS. ELLIS, DAUGHTER OF PRESIDENT TYLER|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1947/07/01/archives/mrs-elljs-daughter-of-president-tyler.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 1, 1947}} She married William Munford Ellis, a former member of the [[Virginia House of Delegates]], and lived near [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]].{{cite news|title=Major William Munford Ellis|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1921/09/11/archives/obituary-1-no-title.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 11, 1921}} Tyler suffered a stroke in [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] and died there at the Exchange Hotel on July 10, 1889, aged 69.{{cite news|title=MRS. JULIA GARDINER TYLER|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F07EEDE143AEF33A25752C1A9619C94689FD7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 11, 1889}} She was buried next to the president at [[Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)|Hollywood Cemetery]] in Richmond.{{cite news|title=Funeral of Mrs. Tyler|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1889/07/13/106355358.pdf|accessdate=March 21, 2017|work=New York Times|date=July 13, 1889}} Her funeral was held in Richmond at St. Peter's Cathedral on July 12, 1889, and was attended by Governor [[Fitzhugh Lee]] and Mayor [[James Taylor Ellyson]], with the absolution performed by Bishop [[Augustine Van de Vyver]].{{cite news|title=FUNERAL OF MRS. TYLER.; FATHER VAN DE VIVER'S TRIBUTE TO THE DECEASED LADY.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1889/07/13/archives/funeral-of-mrs-tyler-father-van-de-vivers-tribute-to-the-deceased.html|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 13, 1889}} ===Legacy=== In [[Bay Shore]], Gardiner's Park, a wide expanse of virgin land with trails leading to the South Shore, Gardiner Drive and Gardiner Manor Elementary School are all named after her family. In 2009, the [[United States Mint]] honored the former First Lady with the issuance of a 24 karat gold coin.{{Cite web|url=http://firstspousecoinguide.com/2009-julia-tyler-first-spouse-coin/ |title=First Spouse Coin Guide}} The papers of the Tyler family, including Julia Gardiner Tyler, are held by the [[Earl Gregg Swem Library#Special Collections Research Center|Special Collections Research Center]] at the [[College of William and Mary]].{{cite web|title=Finding aid for the Tyler Family Papers, Group A|url=http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=6999|publisher=Special Collections Research Center, Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary|accessdate=January 22, 2011}} ==References== '''Notes''' {{Noteslist}} '''Sources''' {{Reflist|30em}} '''Other sources''' *[http://www.whitehouse.gov/history/firstladies/jt10.html White House biography] *[http://www.firstladies.org/biographies/firstladies.aspx?biography=11 Biography], from the [[National First Ladies' Library]]. ==External links== *[http://www.american-presidents.org/2007/03/tyler-courtship-and-wedding.html The Tyler Courtship and Wedding] *[http://scrc.swem.wm.edu/index.php?p=collections/controlcard&id=6999 Finding aid for the Tyler Family Papers, Group A] *[http://firstladies.c-span.org/FirstLady/12/Julia-Tyler.aspx Julia Tyler] at [[C-SPAN]]'s ''[[First Ladies: Influence & Image]]'' {{s-start}} {{s-hon}} {{s-bef|before=[[Priscilla Cooper Tyler|Priscilla Tyler]]
''[[De facto]]''}} {{s-ttl|title=[[First Lady of the United States]]|years=1844–1845}} {{s-aft|after=[[Sarah Childress Polk|Sarah Polk]]}} {{s-end}} {{US First Ladies}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tyler, Julia Gardiner}} [[Category:1820 births]] [[Category:1889 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century American women]] [[Category:19th-century Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of Scottish descent]] [[Category:Burials at Hollywood Cemetery (Richmond, Virginia)]] [[Category:Converts to Roman Catholicism from Calvinism]] [[Category:First Ladies of the United States]] [[Category:Gardiner family]] [[Category:John Tyler family|Julia Gardiner Tyler]] [[Category:People from Bay Shore, New York]] [[Category:People from Charles City County, Virginia]] [[Category:People from East Hampton (town), New York]] [[Category:People from Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Staten Island]] [[Category:Spouses of members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:American proslavery activists]] [[Category:Catholics from Virginia]] [[Category:Catholics from New York (state)]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Leo Melamed | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Leibel Melamdovich | birth_date = {{b-da|March 20, 1932}} | birth_place = [[Białystok|Bialystok]], [[Second Polish Republic|Poland]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = Chicago, U.S. | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = | employer = | occupation = Attorney, financier | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = Isaac Melamdovich | relatives = }} '''Leo Melamed''' (born March 20, 1932) is an American attorney, finance executive, and a pioneer of [[financial future]]s. He is the chairman emeritus of [[CME Group]] (formerly the [[Chicago Mercantile Exchange]]).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/280c8690-fd74-11e1-8e36-00144feabdc0.html#axzz27d3FBiNq|title=CME Group to launch renminbi futures|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=September 13, 2012}}</ref>
== Personal life == Melamed was born Leibel Melamdovich to a [[Jewish]] family<ref>[http://forward.com/articles/200802/leo-melamed-retraces-path-of-escape-from-nazis-to/?p=all Jewish Daily Forward: "Leo Melamed Retraces Path of Escape From Nazis to Japanese Port - Mercantile Exchange Chief Rescued by 'Japanese Schindler'" By Nathan Guttman] June 27, 2014</ref> in [[Białystok|Bialystok]], Poland, in 1932 to Isaac Melamdovich, a mathematics teacher.<ref name="ReferenceA">[http://www.leomelamed.com/biosketch.html Leo Melamed Biography on LeoMelamed.com]</ref> In 1939, at the outbreak of World War II, the family fled to [[Lithuania]] to avoid capture by the Nazis. In 1940, the Japanese [[consul general]] to Lithuania, [[Chiune Sugihara]], issued his family a life-saving transit visa, and they made the long trek across [[Siberia]] to safe haven in Japan.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/finance-and-economics/21577387-biggest-financial-exchange-you-have-never-heard-futures-capitalism CME Group: The futures of capitalism], [[The Economist]], May 11th 2013</ref> They crossed the Pacific to the United States in the spring of 1941, and the family settled in [[Chicago]].<ref>[http://forward.com/articles/200802/leo-melamed-retraces-path-of-escape-from-nazis-to/?p=all Leo Melamed Retraces Path of Escape From Nazis to Japanese Port], Jewish Daily Forward, June 27, 2014</ref> Melamed is an avid [[contract bridge]] competitor and often pairs with his <ref>{{cite news|title=Daily Bulletin|url=http://web2.acbl.org/nabcbulletins/2006summer/db2.pdf|accessdate=27 October 2017|date=July 15, 2006|pages=16}}</ref> wife, Betty.
== Career== [[File:Leo Melamed Shinzo Abe and Tsuyoshi Takagi 20140701 1.jpg|thumb|200px|with [[Shinzō Abe]] and [[Tsuyoshi Takagi]] (at the [[Prime Minister's Official Residence]] on July 1, 2014)]] Melamed, an attorney by profession, became involved in futures trading by accident. In law school he was looking for a law clerk job and answered a want ad from a firm looking for a 'runner', thinking the firm, [[Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Beane]], with that many names could be nothing but an established law firm, looking for a clerk to run to court. He worked as a runner in the produce futures markets of the CME throughout law school, learning about the business. He practiced law until 1965 and was elected to the CME board in 1967.<ref>"The World According to Leo Melamed," Derivatives Strategy, April 1998</ref>
Melamed became chairman of the [[Chicago Mercantile Exchange]] in 1969. In 1972, under his leadership, the CME created the [[International Monetary Market]] (IMM), the world's first financial futures exchange, and launched currency futures. In the years that followed, Melamed led the CME and IMM in the creation of a number of financial instruments, including futures on [[United States Treasury security#Treasury bill|US Treasury bills]] in 1976, [[Eurodollars]] in 1981, and stock [[Index Futures|index futures]] in 1982.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
In 1987, Melamed spearheaded the creation and introduction of [[Globex]], the world's first electronic trading system, and became its founding chairman.
Throughout the next three decades and into the 21st century, Melamed held many CME titles including: Special Counsel to the Board; Chairman of the Executive Committee; and Senior Policy Advisor, but remained the acknowledged leader of the CME. In 2002, he led the CME membership to become the first U.S. financial exchange to go public.
In 2014 he was a board member of [[CME Group]] and chairman of its Strategic Steering Committee.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cmegroup.mediaroom.com/index.php?s=43&item=2773|title=CME Group Foundation Launched With More Than $600,000 in Grants|work=CME Group|date=December 28, 2008}}</ref>
In 1991 he founded his own consulting firm, Melamed & Associates, of which he is chairman and [[chief executive officer]]. He used to be a member of the global markets advisory committee of the U.S. [[Commodity Futures Trading Commission]] (CFTC) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cftc.gov/aboutthecftc/globalmarketsadvisorycommittee/gmac_members.html|title=Global Markets Advisory Committee Members|publisher=U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission|date=December 29, 2008}}</ref> and has served as a special advisor on futures markets to governments worldwide. Melamed serves on the prestigious Chinese International Advisory Council of Chinese Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC).
== Recognition and awards== Twenty years after their inception, Nobel Laureate in Economics, [[Merton Miller]], named [[financial futures]] "the most significant innovation of the past two decades." At the close of 1999, the former editor of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' named Melamed "among the ten most important Chicagoans in business of the 20th Century."
He was named a [[The Lincoln Academy of Illinois|Lincoln Laureate]] in 2016 in the area of Business, Industry & Communications.<ref>http://thelincolnacademyofillinois.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/Governors-press-release.2.12.16.pdf</ref>
==Bibliography== Melamed has lectured and written extensively on the markets. His published works include:<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Leo-Melamed/e/B001KCHAYQ/ Amazon: Leo Melamed]</ref> * ''The Tenth Planet'' (Bonus Books, 1984), ([[Science fiction]]) * ''Merits of Flexible Exchange Rates: An Anthology,'' Editor (George Mason University Press, 1988) ASIN: B000M3U0VO * ''Leo Melamed on The Markets: Twenty Years of Financial History as Seen by the Man Who Revolutionized the Markets'' (John Wiley & Sons, 1992), {{ISBN|0-471-57524-0}} * ''Escape to the Futures'', (John Wiley & Sons, 1996), {{ISBN|0-471-11215-1}} prize-winning memoirs which have been published in Chinese, Japanese, Korean and Russian * ''For Crying Out Loud'', (John Wiley & Sons; 2009), memoirs continuation, translated into Chinese and Japanese
==Honors== *[[File:JPN Kyokujitsu-sho 2Class BAR.svg|55px|ribbon bar]] [[Order of the Rising Sun|Order of the Rising Sun, 2nd Class, Gold and Silver Star]] (2017) *Inducted as a Laureate of [[The Lincoln Academy of Illinois]] and awarded the [[The Lincoln Academy of Illinois|Order of Lincoln]] (the State’s highest honor) by the Governor of Illinois in 2016 in the area of Business, Industry, & Communication.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thelincolnacademyofillinois.org/4632-2/#toggle-id-3|title=Leo Melamed on The Lincoln Academy of Illinois website|last=|first=|date=|website=The Lincoln Academy of Illinois|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=January 9, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Sources== * "A Titan Returns to Shake Up CME's Executive Committee", ''The Wall Street Journal'', Feb. 10, 1997
==External links== * [http://www.derivativesstrategy.com/magazine/archive/1995-1996/0496qa.asp The World According to Leo Melamed], Derivatives Strategy, April 1998 * [http://www.tradersnation.com/player/?id=448 For Crying Out Loud], Traders Nation, Interview by Kurt Schemers, Sept. 2009 * [http://www.leomelamed.com/ Personal website] * {{C-SPAN|Leo Melamed}}

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:Khe Sanh LAPES C-130.jpg|thumb|right|[[C-130 Hercules]] dropping pallet with Low Altitude Parachute Extraction System on Khe Sanh runway.]] [[File:C130lapes.jpg|thumb|right|A [[C-130 Hercules|C-130]] performing a Low Altitude Parachute Extraction.]] [[File:C-130 airdrop.jpg|thumb|right|An [[M551 Sheridan]] being dropped from a [[C-130 Hercules]].]]
The '''low-altitude parachute-extraction system''' ('''LAPES''') is a tactical military [[airlift]] delivery method where a [[fixed wing]] [[cargo aircraft]] can deposit supplies in situations in which [[landing]] is not an option, in an area that is too small to accurately [[parachute]] supplies from a high altitude.
This method was developed by the [[US Military]] with the assistance of the 109th Quartermaster Company (Air Drop) in 1964. In May 1965, a detachment of the 109th was formed as the 383rd Quartermaster (Aerial Supply) Detachment and sent to Vietnam. In 1966 the 109th was sent to Vietnam and took operational control of the 383rd. Both units provided Air Drop and LAPES support during the [[Siege of Khe Sanh]] in the [[Vietnam War]]. LAPES was used to provide a method of supplying heavy loads into Khe Sanh which could not effectively be supplied by air drop.<ref name=KheSanh/> This practice was perfected at [[Mactan Air Base]] in [[Cebu]], [[Philippines]].
Preparation for a LAPES delivery includes loading cargo on a [[pallet]] rigged with two types of parachutes (chutes). The drogue chute is used to pull a cluster of larger extraction chutes out. The deployed extraction chutes will then pull the load out of the plane. Floor locks hold the pallet in place until extraction time.
The LAPES delivery procedure begins by slowing to approach speed, lowering the ramp, and opening the cargo door. To preclude damage to the aircraft from an inadvertent contact with the ground, the landing gear is lowered. The aircraft approaches the extraction zone in a manner similar to landing. On command of the pilot, the drogue chute is released and allowed to trail behind the aircraft on a tether. As the pilot flares and achieves a wheel height of 1-2 meters above ground, the drogue chute is allowed to pull the extraction chutes out into the airstream. The force of these chutes overcomes the floor locks, pulling the pallet across the ramp, out of the aircraft, and onto the extraction zone. The pilot adjusts the flight controls to remain level during the extreme change in the aircraft center of gravity caused by the pallet movement. While the pallet slides to a stop using the extraction chutes as a brake, the pilot climbs away from the extraction zone and raises the landing gear. On climb out, the rear cargo door is closed and the ramp is raised, completing the sequence.
LAPES enables planes to quickly deploy large cargo in a timely fashion instead of having to land and take off, which exposes the plane to enemy fire. The technique also allows delivery of loads that are too heavy for a direct parachute descent (high altitude drop). However, the drop sequence's low altitude allows for no margin of [[pilot error]] and the risk of [[plane crash]] is heightened.<ref name="KheSanh">{{cite news|title=The Siege of Khe Sanh|url=https://www.pbs.org/battlefieldvietnam/khe/g_02.html|author=Geiger, Bruce M|work=PBS}}</ref>
On July 1, 1987, during a [[capabilities exercise]] (CAPEX), a USAF C-130E (68-10945 c/n 4325) crashed while performing a LAPES demo at the Sicily Drop Zone, on Fort Bragg. The pilot of the C-130 had performed a LAPES drop with the same extreme rate of descent two days earlier during a practice run. The crash killed three on board and one soldier on the ground, and injured two crew.<ref name="Ft Bragg">{{cite news |title=Plane Crashes in Military Exercise, Narrowly Missing Spectators|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/us/plane-crashes-in-military-exercise-narrowly-missing-spectators.html|date=2 July 1987|work=New York Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171106044910/https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/02/us/plane-crashes-in-military-exercise-narrowly-missing-spectators.html|archive-date=6 November 2017|access-date=2 May 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [http://www103.pair.com/adsd/riggers/index.html Riggers Page for Air Drop history. Particularly in Vietnam] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FqPDe-nZK6w C-130 Crash C-130 Hercules Drop Disaster]

revision.text:
A '''market correction''' is a rapid change in the [[nominal price]] of a [[commodity]], after a [[Barriers to trade|barrier]] to [[free trade]] has been removed and the [[free market]] establishes a new [[equilibrium price]]. It may also refer to several of these single-commodity corrections ''en masse'', as a collective effect over several markets concurrently.
== See also == * [[Market trend]] * [[Panic of 1796–1797|Real estate bubble of 1796-1797]] * [[Panic of 1837|Financial Bubble of 1837]] * [[United States housing market correction]] * [[United States housing bubble]]

{{coi|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Michael Recanati | birth_date = June 21 1957 | birth_place= | death_date = {{death-date and age|July 12 2015|June 21 1957}} | death_place= | residence = [[Manhattan, New York]]
[[East Hampton (village), New York|East Hampton]] [[New York (state)|New York]] | nationality = American Israeli | occupation = Businessman, philanthropist | partner = Tom Schalk[http://portal.idc.ac.il/he/main/about_idc/idc_friends/documents/idc-herzliyan-winter-2016.pdf The IDC Herzliyan Winter 2016 Update] | children = 1 | father = [[Raphael Recanati]] | relatives = [[Leon Yehuda Recanati]] (paternal grandfather)
[[Leon Recanati]] (first cousin) [[Avraham Rakanti]] (Great uncle) }} '''Michael Recanati''' (1957–2015) was an American businessman and philanthropist. ==Early life== Michael Recanati was born in 1957.{{cite news|last1=Nassie|first1=Jonathan|title="Bloomberg": Rafael Recanati Dismissed Son from Family Shipping Co Management|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-350660|accessdate=March 12, 2016|work=[[Globes]]|date=November 7, 1996}} His father, [[Raphael Recanati]] was an Israeli-American businessman and philanthropist. Recanati was educated at [[Ramaz School]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. ==Career== Recanati started his career at his family business, the [[Overseas Shipholding Group]], in 1978. He was forced to leave OSG in 1995 after a dispute about the company's investments in cruise ships. Recanati founded Orama, a [[venture capital]] firm based in New York City and [[Tel Aviv]], Israel, in 1999.{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Orama Ltd|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=896750|website=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=March 13, 2016}} It closed down in 2001.{{cite news|last1=Shalev|first1=Shai|title=IDB closing down Orama Partners|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-537476|accessdate=March 13, 2016|work=Globes|date=November 18, 2001}} In 2008, Recanati founded Really Cool Foods, an [[organic food]] company.{{cite news|title=Michael Recanati: The Anti-Midas Touch|url=http://freebeacon.com/democracy-alliance/michael-recanati-the-anti-midas-touch/|accessdate=March 12, 2016|work=[[Washington Free Beacon]]|date=August 15, 2012|first=Bill|last=McMorris}} It closed down in 2011.{{cite news|title=Indiana's Really Cool Foods closes doors|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9RA0QMO1.htm|accessdate=March 13, 2016|work=BusinessWeek|date=November 28, 2011}} Recanati served as the chairman of 511 Equities.{{cite web|title=Company Overview of PEC Israel Economic Corp.: Michael Recanati|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=1204214&privcapId=294536&previousCapId=294536&previousTitle=PEC%20Israel%20Economic%20Corp.|website=Bloomberg Business|accessdate=March 13, 2016}} ==Philanthropy== Recanati endowed the Dina and Raphael Recanati Professorship in Immunology at the [[Harvard Medical School]] in honor of his parents in 1992. Dr [[Jerome Groopman]] is the current chair.{{cite news|last1=Maluf|first1=Nell M.|title=Chair Endowed for AIDS Scientist|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1992/2/19/chair-endowed-for-aids-scientist-pa/|accessdate=March 12, 2016|work=The Crimson|date=February 19, 1992}} He also endowed the Recanati Family Professor of Science and professor of Microbiology and Medicine at the Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine at [[New York University]] https://nyulangone.org/press-releases/internationally-renowned-researcher-from-nyu-langone-medical-center-elected-to-the-national-academy-of-sciences In 2002, Recanati and his partner Ira Statfeld made a $5 million donation to the then Hampton Day School,{{cite web|url=http://easthamptonstar.com/Archive/1/MERGER-When-School-Lets-Out-It’s-Over|title=MERGER: When School Lets Out, It’s Over|first=Amanda|last=Angel|date=June 8, 2006|accessdate=December 24, 2017|work=The East Hampton Star}}{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2003/01/hamptons-high-private-school-is-taken-over/|title=Hamptons High: Private School is Taken Over|work=New York Observer|date=January 6, 2003|accessdate=December 24, 2017}} taking control of the board of trustees and changing the name of the school to the Morriss Center in honor of Statfeld's father,{{cite web|url=http://easthamptonstar.com/Archive/2/New-Era-Dawns-Hampton-Day-School|title=A New Era Dawns At Hampton Day School|first=Susan|last=Rosenbaum|work=The East Hampton Star|date=June 19, 2003|accessdate=December 24, 2017}} however the school merged with the [[Ross School (East Hampton, New York)|Ross School]] in 2006.{{cite web|work=The East Hampton Star|first=Amanda|last=Anegl|url=http://easthamptonstar.com/Archive/2/Ross-School-Morriss-Center-Consolidate-teach-tots-teens-two-campuses-next-year|title=Ross School, Morriss Center to Consolidate to teach tots to teens on two campuses next year|date=January 12, 2006|accessdate=December 24, 2017}} In 2007, it was reported that Recanati and his partner had donated $30 million to the Child Study Center at [[New York University]] to establish an [[Asperger's]] Institute.{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Robert J.|title=Bridging the Rural Charity Gap|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB117703024906976311|accessdate=March 12, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=April 20, 2007}} ==Personal life== Recanati and his partner Ira Statfeld had one son. They resided in Manhattan and East Hampton, New York.{{cite news|last1=Beller|first1=Peter C.|title=Roosterban in Chickenhampton: Late-sleeping summer people do battle with the fowl-loving locals.|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/columns/intelligencer/11919/|accessdate=March 12, 2016|work=New York Magazine|date=June 6, 2005}} His partner at time of death was Tom Schalk. [http://portal.idc.ac.il/he/main/about_idc/idc_friends/documents/idc-herzliyan-winter-2016.pdf The IDC Herzliyan Winter 2016 Update] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Recanati, Michael}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Greek-Jewish descent]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York (state)]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:LGBT businesspeople from the United States]] [[Category:Gay men]] [[Category:Recanati family]]

{{BLP sources|date=March 2018}} [[File:Mohammad Al Duaij, 2017.jpg|thumb]] '''Mohammad Al Duaij''' (born 1980) is a Kuwaiti business man and entrepreneur. He became the chief executive officer of [[Alea Global Group]] in 2008.
He studied accounting and finance at Leeds University and graduated in 2002 and began his career by joining the [[Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development]] as part of the Asian projects funding team. From 2004 to 2008 he worked as financial analyst<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://relationshipscience.com/person/mohammad-al-duaij-112481710|title=Former Financial Analyst|last=|first=|date=|website=Relationship Science|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and investment manager at Global Investment House in Kuwait<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.icvgroup.org/speaker/mohammad-al-duaij/|title=Mohammad Al Duaij|last=|first=|date=|website=ICV|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>.
Since 2008 he is the CEO of his family office Alea Global Group. His family's business began by real estate investments in the gulf region, while Mohammad Al Duaij began to follow other business opportunities, too. Today, Alea Global Group is a conglomerate with a globe-spanning network of direct investments in real estate and private equity, commodities trading, and offers financial and investment advisory services.
In 2015 he became partner at Italian R & P Consulting. In this role he is responsible for the business development and expansion of the firm's business activity in the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/mohammad-al-duaij-b6bb899/|title=LinkedIn Account|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Besides his activity as CEO and partner, he is organizer and host of the Middle East Family Office Investment Summit, a twice-yearly gathering in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Family Offices, either from the Middle East or with an interest in the region follow his invitation to gather for two days to network and initiate business cooperations. The event generally attracts a high number of C-level executives and influential decision-makers from the Gulf. Participation in the conference is by invitation only.
Mohammad Al Duaij is the recipient of several awards. He was named The Man of the Year 2017 by Business Worldwide Publication<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/business-worldwide-magazine-appoints-mohammad-al-duaij-its-man-of-the-year-2017-671897783.html|title=Business Worldwide Magazine Appoints Mohammad Al Duaij its Man of the Year, 2017|last=Jones|first=David|date=31 January 2018|work=PR Newswire|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> for his work ability to maintain excellent professional relationships despite often challenging political circumstances. Further, he is a recipient of the Business Worldwide Magazine's CEO award in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aleaglobalgroup.com/business-worldwide-magazine-ceo-award-winner-2016/|title=BUSINESS WORLDWIDE MAGAZINE – CEO AWARD WINNER 2016 – Alea|website=aleaglobalgroup.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/prnewswire/press_releases/2016/06/03/enUK201606026017|title=Alea Global Group Lifts Two CEO Business Awards|last=|first=|date=3 June 2016|website=The Business Journals|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref> Also in 2016, Alea Global Group received the Global Business Award 'Advisory firm of the year', awarded by The European.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aleaglobalgroup.com/the-advisory-firm-of-the-year-2016/|title=The Advisory Firm of the Year 2016 – Alea|website=aleaglobalgroup.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>
==References== <references />
