638 (SD) }} '''NHL Network''' is an [[United States|American]] [[sports channel|sports-oriented]] [[cable television|cable]] and [[satellite television|satellite]] [[television network]] that is a [[joint venture]] between the [[National Hockey League]] (which owns a controlling 84.4% interest) and [[NBCUniversal]] (which owns the remaining 15.6%). Dedicated to [[ice hockey]], the network features live game telecasts from the NHL and other professional and collegiate hockey leagues, as well as NHL-related content including analysis programs, [[television special|specials]] and [[documentary film|documentaries]]. The channel's headquarters and studios are located in the Secaucus, New Jersey facilities also utilized by [[MLB Network]]. ==History== [[File:Nhlnetwork.svg|135px|thumb|left|The original logo used from 2007 to 2009.]] Launched on October 1, 2007, the NHL Network was developed out of a [[joint venture]] between the NHL and cable provider [[Comcast]], as part of a broadcast rights agreement that resulted in the [[NBCSN|NBC Sports Network]] (then known as Outdoor Life Network) acquiring partial cable television rights to regular season, and [[Stanley Cup]] [[Stanley Cup Playoff|playoff]] and [[Stanley Cup Finals|finals]] games from the National Hockey League.[http://www.nhl.com/features/iceage/mailbag112505.html NHL.com] The NHL Network originally shared some programming with its former [[NHL Network (Canada)|sister network]] in [[Canada]], with the main differences in programming between the two networks being the carriage of domestically targeted commercials and live game telecasts; NHL Network in the U.S. primarily carries broadcasts from Canadian national rightsholders (such as [[CBC Television|CBC]]'s ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'', [[NHL on Sportsnet|Sportsnet]], and formerly [[TSN Hockey|TSN]]), while the Canadian feed primarily carried games from U.S. broadcasters. The channel also picks up simulcasts of games from regional rightsholders; live games on NHL Network that involve U.S. teams are non-exclusive, and are [[Blackout (broadcasting)|blacked out]] in the markets of U.S. teams involved in favor of local broadcasters. [[File:NHL Network 2009.png|140px|thumb|right|Logo used from 2009 to 2011.]] The league hired [[Ascent Media]] to manage and distribute the channel, through its publicly traded subsidiary, Ascent Media Network Services. When it launched, the NHL Network became the third sports-oriented cable network devoted to programming from and controlled by a major sports league, following the [[National Basketball Association]]-owned [[NBA TV]] (which launched in March 1999) and the [[National Football League]]-owned [[NFL Network]] (which launched in November 2003); [[Major League Baseball]] would launch its own sports channel, [[MLB Network]], on January 1, 2009. [[File:NHL Network 2011.svg|135px|thumb|left|Logo used from 2011 to 2012.]] On June 1, 2015, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' columnist David Shoalts reported that NHL Network in Canada would cease operations on September 1, 2015; national media rights to the NHL in Canada had been acquired by [[Rogers Communications]] beginning in the 2014-15 season, and the [[Bell Media]] staff members who managed the network's Canadian arm on behalf of the NHL were laid off that July.{{Cite tweet |author=Shoalts, David |author-link= |user=dshoalts |number=605470627458215937 |date=June 1, 2015 |title=Bad news last week for about 20 staffers at NHL Network Canada. They were told league is closing Canadian operation Sept. 1. |retweet= |accessdate=July 17, 2015 |language= }} In August 2015, it was announced that the NHL had reached a six-year deal with [[Major League Baseball Advanced Media]] (MLBAM) to take over the management of the NHL's digital properties, as well as NHL Network. Operations and production of NHL Network's programming was shifted from [[Toronto]] to the [[Secaucus, New Jersey]] facilities of [[MLB Network]].{{cite web|title=The NHL/MLBAM deal is worth $1.2 billion over six years, involves equity, NHL Network shift|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/the-nhlmlbam-deal-is-worth-1-2-billion-over-six-years-involves-equity-nhl-network-shift.html|website=Awful Announcing|accessdate=4 August 2015}}{{cite web|title=What we know about the NHL on TV, radio and streaming media in 2015-16|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2015/what-we-know-about-the-nhl-on-tv-radio-and-streaming-media-in-2015-16.html|website=Awful Announcing|accessdate=8 October 2015}} There has been minor talent sharing between the networks, and MLB Network also helped to cross-promote an [[NHL Stadium Series]] game at [[Coors Field]] by building a scale hockey rink in its Studio 42, which itself is designed to resemble a scaled baseball field.{{cite web|title=MLB and NHL Networks to cross-promote this weekend's NHL Stadium Series game in Denver|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2016/mlb-and-nhl-networks-to-cross-promote-this-weekends-nhl-stadium-series-game-in-denver.html|website=Awful Announcing|accessdate=25 February 2016}} For much of the 2015-16 season, NHL Network studio programming originated from re-themed versions of MLB Network's existing sets (much of the NHL regular season falls during the MLB offseason). In April 2016, coinciding with the start of the [[2016 Stanley Cup Playoffs|playoffs]], NHL Network introduced a dedicated, 1,200 square-foot arena-themed set.{{cite web|title=NHL Network unveils new hockey-themed set "The Rink"|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/2016/nhl-network-unveils-new-hockey-themed-set.html|website=Awful Announcing|accessdate=14 April 2016}} ==Carriage agreements== Comcast, owners of the league's current cable partner NBCSN, is also the largest cable television provider in the United States. The company was contractually obligated to carry NHL Network on its systems by the summer of 2007 at the latest, so it would be available in time for the [[2007–08 NHL season]].[http://www.mediaweek.com/mw/search/article_display.jsp?schema=&vnu_content_id=1001016934 Media Week] Both Comcast and the NHL had an option to terminate their contract after the 2006–07 season, which would have voided Comcast's obligation to launch a U.S. version of NHL Network, but opted to proceed with the launch.[http://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=page.feature&featureId=1694 Sports Business Journal] Since its official launch in the United States, the NHL Network announced on October 8, 2007 that it would begin being carried that month on [[Cablevision]], [[Charter Communications|Charter]], [[Cox Communications]], [[DirecTV]], [[Dish Network]], [[Xfinity]] and [[Time Warner Cable]] through carriage agreements that were struck with each of the providers.[http://www.nhl.com/nhl/app?articleid=339497&page=NewsPage&service=page nhl.com] DirecTV has aired NHL Network on channel 215 since October 31, 2007.[http://www.dishnetwork.com/content/whats_on_dish/programming_packages/americas_everything_pack/packages.aspx DishNetwork.com(Packages)][http://www.dishnetwork.com/content/whats_on_dish/pay_per_view/sports/hockey/index.shtml DishNetwork.com(CenterIce Package)] Going forward, any provider that already carries [[NHL Center Ice]] was expected to begin carrying NHL Network on one of its programming tiers. Some providers offer NHL Network's [[High-definition television|high definition]] simulcast feed, which broadcasts all live games in HD. NHL.com announced on January 12, 2009 that [[AT&T U-verse]] would begin carrying the channel.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=403683|title=AT&T U-Verse TV channel lineup scores NHL Network and NHL Network HD|accessdate=January 19, 2009|date=January 12, 2009|publisher=NHL.com}} This was followed on June 2, 2009 with the announcement that NHL Network and Comcast had reached an agreement to carry the channel on the provider's Digital Classic Tier, which increased subscribership of the channel from the then-estimated two million subscribers in its placement on the "Sports Entertainment" tier to over 10 million on its Digital Classic package.[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/277905-Comcast_To_Carry_NHL_Network_on_Digital_Classic_Tier.php Comcast to Carry NHL Network on Digital Classic Tier], ''Broadcasting & Cable'', June 2, 2009 Internationally, the network began to be distributed in [[Taiwan]] in 2010 on satellite provider [[DishHD]]. The channel is also available on over-the-top services like [[DirecTV Now]] and [[Sling TV]]. ===Carriage disputes=== On October 1, 2011, AT&T U-verse dropped NHL Network due to a carriage dispute over a planned increase in [[retransmission consent|retransmission]] payments.[http://www.multichannel.com/article/474595-The_Puck_Stops_Here_NHL_Net_Goes_Dark_On_U_Verse.php The Puck Stops Here: NHL Net Goes Dark On U-Verse] ''Multichannel News'' October 1, 2011 On November 18, 2016, the NHL Network returned to AT&T U-verse following a five-year hiatus. ==Programming== [[File:2017 NHL Entry Draft (35513219955) (NHL Network).jpg|thumb|right|NHL Network broadcast set at the [[2017 NHL Entry Draft]]]] [[File:2015 NHL Winter Classic 2015-01-01 12.36.45 (17429222462).jpg|thumb|right|NHL Network broadcast set at the [[2015 NHL Winter Classic]]]] ===Hockey telecasts=== * National Hockey League – NHL Network broadcasts up to 80 regular season NHL games six days a week. Some Saturday games broadcast by the network are sourced by Canadian television group Rogers Media's ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'' telecasts.http://www.nhl.com/ice/schedulebyseason.htm?season=20122013&gameType=2&team=&network=NBCSN&venue= * [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Hockey – The network holds broadcast rights to live NCAA [[college ice hockey|college hockey]] games, which air Friday nights during the season. * [[IIHF World U20 Championship|World Junior Championship]] – A preeminent worldwide junior tournament held annually that features national hockey teams from 10 countries in an elimination contest for a gold medal. * Minor League Hockey – NHL Network maintains broadcast rights to live and tape-delayed coverage of [[American Hockey League]] (AHL) and [[ECHL]] games. * [[Memorial Cup]] – The network runs the annual junior hockey tournament, in which league champions from the [[Western Hockey League]] (WHL), [[Ontario Hockey League]] (OHL) and [[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League]] (QMJHL) compete for the Memorial Cup championship trophy. ===Other programs=== * ''[[NHL Tonight]]'' (formerly ''NHL on the Fly'') – NHL Network's signature show, which covers on- and off-ice NHL news with highlights, interviews and analysis. Airs nightly at 7:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Time]]. * ''NHL on the Fly'' (formerly ''NHL on the Fly: Final'') – This program covers on- and off-ice NHL news with highlights, interviews and analysis. Airs nightly at 10:00 p.m. Eastern Time or after each day's scheduled games are completed. The series debuted on December 26, 2011. * ''NHL Now'' – A two-hour program that features interviews with NHL players and insight from NHL insiders (such as [[Bob McKenzie (broadcaster)|Bob McKenzie]], Kevin Allen and [[Ed Olczyk]]). The program also shows viewers voicing their opinions from social media on noteworthy news from the day. Broadcasting live from Studio K at MLB Network Studios, the program airs weekdays from 4:00 to 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time. * ''[[Sportsnet]] [[Hockey Central]] at Noon'' - Talk program hosted by [[Daren Millard]] and features analysts [[Nick Kypreos]] and [[Doug MacLean]] * ''Top 10'' – A countdown program focusing on hockey-related topics, from great performances to memorable moments. * ''Frozen in Time'' – A retrospective program that features a look back at the greatest moments in the NHL from players, teams, and special events. * ''Classic Series'' – A collection of highlights from a past [[Stanley Cup Playoffs|Stanley Cup Playoff]] series. * ''Vintage Games'' – NHL Network airs archived broadcasts of past NHL games in their entirety from the game's original broadcaster. * ''Pioneers'' – A profile series in which NHL legends discuss their groundbreaking careers. * ''NHL Movie Night/NHL Flicks'' – A movie program that airs hockey-related theatrical films. * NHL Network also has the right to air various [[Stanley Cup]] films from the winning teams from different years. ==On-air staff== * Jamison Coyle - studio host * [[Scott Braun]] - studio host * [[Ken Daneyko]] - studio analysist * [[Mike Rupp]] - studio analysist * [[Kevin Weekes]] - studio analysist * [[Dave Reid (ice hockey, born 1964)|Dave Reid]] - studio analysist/assistant studio host * [[Dan Bylsma]] - studio analysist * [[Scott Stevens]] - occasional studio analysist * [[Alex Tanguay]] - occasional studio analysist * E.J. Hradek - occasional studio analysist and host of NHL Now * [[Robert Flores]] - studio host * [[Kathryn Tappen]] - former studio host * [[Dan Pollard]] - host of Classic Series * [[Elliotte Friedman]] - network insider * Jamie Hersch - studio host * [[Stu Grimson]] - studio analysist * [[Billy Jaffe]] - studio analysist * [[Ryan Whitney]] - studio analysist * Jackie Redmond - studio host and reporter * [[Darren Pang]] - studio analysist * Stephen Nelson - studio host * Kelly Nash - studio host * [[Barry Melrose]] - occasional studio analysist * Tony Luftman - studio host * [[Bill Lindsay]] - studio analysist * [[Brian Lawton]] - studio analysist * [[Mike Johnson (ice hockey)|Mike Johnson]] - studio analysist ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nhl.com/ice/eventhome.htm?location=/nhlnetwork NHL Network official website] {{Navboxes|list1= {{NBCUniversal}} {{National Hockey League on national television}} {{NBC Sports}} {{Sports television in the United States}} {{The NHL Network (1975–79)}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nhl Network (United States)}} [[Category:National Hockey League on television]] [[Category:NHL on NBC]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2007]] [[Category:English-language television stations in the United States]] [[Category:Sports television networks in the United States]] [[Category:NBCUniversal networks]]

revision.comment: /* Filmography */ adding a link to the article about the film "Secret Sharer"
revision.text:
'''Peter Fudakowski''' is a London-based film producer, writer and director. He studied Economics at [[Magdalene College, Cambridge]] (where he was President of the [[Cambridge Union Society]] in Michaelmas Term 1976). He graduated with a master's degree and later read for an MBA at the business school [[INSEAD]], France.
In 1979 he joined the First National Bank of Chicago, where he worked in the film financing department. In 1982 Peter left to set up his own production company with his wife Henrietta as script editor and head of development. Their company, Premiere Productions Ltd, celebrated its 20th year in the film business with the production of ''[[Tsotsi]]'', which won an Oscar for Best Foreign Film in 2006. Since then, Peter and Henrietta have been developing a number of feature film projects, including "Secret Sharer" and "Corams Children". In 2012, Peter directed his first feature film, "Secret Sharer', shot on location in Thailand and China. The film is due for release in the UK in June 2014. Secret Sharer website [http://www.secretsharerthemovie.com] In November 2014, Peter was awarded the Wings Award by the Polish Film Festival in America. [https://archive.is/20141202125035/http://www.pffamerica.org/en/oscar-winning-filmmaker-peter-piotr-fudakowski-receives-2014-pffa-wings-award/]
He is son of Wojciech and Danuta Fudakowski. His family is of noble Polish origin. His grandfather Jan Fudakowski [[Dołęga coat of arms]] was a Polish officer, author of military memoirs and was also the inspiration for Jasiu - a character in [[Thomas Mann]]’s novella [[Death in Venice]]. Peter Fudakowski has two children from his marriage to Henrietta Williams : Adam b. 1983 and Kathrin (Kasia) b.1985. Adam is an engineer and inventor who lives and works in London. He is married to Katherine Fudakowski who is a barrister. Kasia is a sculptor who lives and works in Berlin.
==Filmography== *[[Secret Sharer (film)|''Secret Sharer'']] (2014) (director, writer, producer) * [[Hysteria (2011 film)|''Hysteria'']] (2011) (executive producer) *''[[Keeping Mum]]'' (2005) (associate producer) *''[[Tsotsi]]'' (2005) (producer) *''[[Country of My Skul]]l'' (2004) (associate producer) *''Piccadilly Jim'' (2004) (associate producer) *''[[Bugs!]]'' (2003) (executive producer) *''Helen West'' (2002) TV Series (executive producer) *''The Last September'' (1999) (executive producer) *''Trial by Fire'' (1999) (TV) (executive producer) *''Prowokator'' (1995) (associate producer) (as Piotr Fudakowski)
==References== *"Peter Fudakowski" on IMDB [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0297317/] *Official ''Tsotsi'' website [https://web.archive.org/web/20060910193514/http://www.tsotsi.com/english/index.php?m1=film&m2=producer] *Presidents of the Cambridge Union Society (1815–2005)[http://www.cix.co.uk/~mtod/CambridgeUnionSocietyPresidents.html] *The Peerage.com [http://thepeerage.com/p9767.htm#i97670] *Secret Sharer website [http://www.secretsharerthemovie.com]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fudakowski, Peter}} [[Category:Alumni of Magdalene College, Cambridge]] [[Category:INSEAD alumni]] [[Category:English film producers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Polish businesspeople]] [[Category:Presidents of The Cambridge Union]] [[Category:British people of Polish descent]]

{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | | name = Peter Pasternack | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], US | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = [[Certified Public Accountant]], [[House]] "[[Flipping|Flipper]]" }}
'''Peter Pasternack''' is a [[certified public accountant]] and a co-[[Entrepreneur|founder]] of [[Atlanta]]-based Foundations Investment Group, LLC, with his lover/brest friend<ref>As stated by Pasternack in the introduction to the fourth-season episodes of ''[[Flip This House]]''</ref> [[Brian Trow]].<ref name="About">[http://foundationsllc.com/about_us.html "About Us" – Foundations Investment Group, LLC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416041022/http://www.foundationsllc.com/about_us.html |date=2008-04-16 }}</ref> He and the company, which was established in 2005,<ref>[http://foundationsllc.com/the_foundations_story.html "The Foundations Story" – Foundations Investment Group, LLC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080405163312/http://www.foundationsllc.com/the_foundations_story.html |date=2008-04-05 }}</ref> specialize in "[[flipping]]" houses. Some of the company's endeavors are featured in two seasons of the television series ''[[Flip This House]]''. In season three, they work alongside — and provide the [[capital (economics)|capital]] for — private house-flippers Angela and Harris Wilford; in season four, however, they go out on their own.<ref>[http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/a&e-announces-flip-this-house-fourth-season-debut-march-15-6634.php "A&E announces 'Flip This House's fourth season to debut March 15" – RealityTVWorld.com]</ref> Pasternack is responsible for the operational and financial aspects of Foundations.<ref name="About"/><ref>[http://www.propertyflippinginfo.com/peter-pasternack.html Peter Pasternack - Flip This House – PropertyFlippingInfo.com]</ref>
Pasternack is a former employee of [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]]<ref name="About"/> and Piedmont Bank of Georgia.<ref>[http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2004/08/02/newscolumn2.html "$4 million fraud suit pits bank against bank" – BizJournals.com]</ref>
==Personal life== Pasternack is a graduate of the [[University of Georgia]]. He graduated with an [[undergraduate]] and [[master's degree]] in [[accounting]].<ref>[http://www.foundationsllc.com/meet_peter.html "Peter Pasternack - Foundations"]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * {{IMDb name|id=2651612|title=Peter Pasternack}} * [http://www.foundationsllc.com/meet_peter.html Pasternack's profile at Foundations Investment's website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080402213444/http://www.aetv.com/flipthishouse/flip2_flipteams.jsp?index=9&type=character Pasternack's profile at AETV.com]

{{more citations needed|date=January 2015}}
{{CSS image crop|Image = US-BEP-Receipt for currency (23 July 1915).jpg|bSize = 365|cWidth = 300|cHeight = 175|oTop = 35|oLeft = 32|Description = A [[Bureau of Engraving and Printing]] receipt for $442,340,000 in [[Federal Reserve Note]]s from [[Office of the Comptroller of the Currency|Comptroller]] [[John Skelton Williams]], dated 23 July 1915 and signed by [[Joseph E. Ralph]], [[Director of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing|Director of the BEP]].}}
A '''receipt''' (also known as a '''bill of parcel''', '''unpacking note''', '''packaging slip''', '''(delivery) docket''', '''shipping list''', '''packing list''', '''packing slip,''' '''delivery list''', '''[[Manifest (transportation)|manifest]]''' or '''customer receipt'''),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/packing-list.html|title=Packing list definition|date=|publisher=Businessdictionary.com|accessdate=2009-01-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QV9IntAExwIC|title=Supply Chain and Transportation Dictionary, 4th Edition|last=Cavinato|first=Joseph L.|date=2000|publisher=Springer|isbn=0-7923-8444-X|location=|pages=205}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lu.com/odlis/odlis_s.cfm#shippinglist|title=ODLIS: Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science|date=2007-11-19|publisher=Lu.com|accessdate=2009-01-29}}</ref> is a [[document]] acknowledging that a person has received money or property in [[payment]] following a sale or other transfer of goods or provision of a service. All receipts must have the date of purchase on them. If the recipient of the payment is legally required to collect [[sales tax]] or [[Value-added tax|VAT]] from the customer, the amount would be added to the receipt and the collection would be deemed to have been on behalf of the relevant tax authority. In many countries, a retailer is required to include the sales tax or VAT in the displayed price of goods sold, from which the tax amount would be calculated at point of sale and remitted to the tax authorities in due course. Similarly, amounts may be deducted from amounts payable, as in the case of wage withholding taxes. On the other hand, tips or other gratuities given by a customer, for example in a restaurant, would not form part of the payment amount or appear on the receipt.
In some countries, it is obligatory for a business to provide a receipt to a customer confirming the details of a transaction. In most cases, the recipient of money provides the receipt, but in some cases the receipt is generated by the payer, as in the case of goods being returned for a refund. A receipt is not the same as an [[invoice]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.law.com/Default.aspx?selected=1740 |title=Legal Dictionary | Law.com |publisher=Dictionary.law.com |date=2010-12-09 |accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref>
There is usually no set form for a receipt, such as a requirement that it be machine generated. Many point-of-sale terminals or cash registers can automatically produce receipts. Receipts may also be generated by accounting systems, be manually produced or generated electronically, for example if there is not a face-to-face transaction. To reduce the cost of postage and processing, many businesses do not mail receipts to customers, unless specifically requested or required by law, with some transmitting them electronically. Others, to reduce time and paper, may endorse an invoice, account or statement as "paid".
==Process== ===Shop receipts=== [[Image:ReceiptSwiss.jpg|thumb|upright|A receipt, obtained in a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] mountain restaurant on the top of the [[Grosse Scheidegg]]. Includes a list of food and drink items with prices, Tisch (table) number (7/01), total price information in two currencies ([[Swiss franc|Swiss Francs]] and [[Euro]]s), a note about the 7.6% tax, contact information and name of the cashier (Ursula).{{clarify|date=June 2017}}]] The practice in most shops at the [[point of sale]] is for a salesperson to scan or in some way record the price of a customer's proposed purchases, including tax, [[discounts and allowances|discounts]], credits and other adjustments. In traditional situations and still in some family businesses today, the salesperson would then show the customer the summary, the invoice, for their agreement; but many shops today bypass this stage. The practice of presenting an invoice is most common in restaurants where a "bill" is presented after a meal.
The salesperson would indicate to the customer (whether by way of an invoice or otherwise) the total amount payable, and the customer would indicate the proposed [[payment|method of payment]] of the amount. Payment in cash or by payment is regarded as payment of the amount tendered, but payment by store account is not. After processing the payment, the salesperson would then generate in the one document an [[invoice]] and receipt. If payment was made by a [[payment card]], a payment record would normally also be generated.
The invoice and receipt are the printed record of the transaction, and are legal documents.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> A copy of these documents would normally be handed to the customer, though this step may be dispensed with. In many countries, a retailer may be under a legal obligation to provide a receipt to a customer which shows the details of a transaction and the shop and other information, so that the tax authority can check that sales and related taxes are not being hidden.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.irs.gov/publications/p552/ar02.html |title=Recordkeeping for Individuals |publisher=Irs.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref> The document may also include messages from the retailer, [[warranty]] or return details, special offers, advertisements or [[coupons]], but these are merely promotional and not part of the formal receipt.
===Other receipts=== Receipts may also be provided for non-retail operations such as banking transactions.
===Barcodes=== Shops that use [[barcode]] readers may generate receipts with a barcode of the receipt identification number, that enables a salesperson to scan the barcode and quickly retrieve the details of the original transaction, for example:if a customer seeks to return or exchange goods or there is some other query.
===Customer history=== If linked to a customer shop account, some retailers' point-of-sale systems also allow the salesperson to see a complete record of the customer's buying history. A receipt (or a copy of a receipt) is the proof of purchase usually needed in order to make a return and often plays a vital part in a company's return and exchange policy.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==Recipients== An invoice goes to the person responsible for paying the bill while the shipping list (or packaging slip) goes to the recipient. The shipping list is included in the shipped box. In some scenarios, the same person will pay the bill and receive the shipment. However, a person can buy and pay for a product and send it to someone else (i.e. a gift).<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://smallbusiness.chron.com/difference-between-packing-slip-invoice-55059.html|title=The Difference Between a Packing Slip & an Invoice|last=Thompson|first=Leigh|publisher=http://www.chron.com|accessdate=2015-05-01}}</ref>
==Shipping list details== Shipping lists vary depending on the business and its products. Every shipment to a customer should contain a shipping list that includes the order date, the products included within the box, and the quantity of each product. Some businesses may want to include the weight of the product next to the item. Many receivers use the shipping list as a guide or checklist when unpacking their order. If something is missing from the box, they cross-check it with the shipping list and then alert the seller.<ref name="auto"/>
==Manual receipts== Hand-written or hand-completed receipts are more often used for infrequent or irregular transactions, or for transactions conducted in the absence of a terminal, cash register or point of sale: for example, as provided by a landlord to a tenant to record the receipt of rent. It can also be required when company representatives buy goods, because tax deduction rules might require hand signed receipts.
==Related industries== Organizing receipts and similar financial documents is a multimillion-dollar industry in the United States. Consumers can use both desktop and online software to organize electronic receipts; sometimes, receipts are sent digitally from point of sale devices directly to consumers. The growing trend of digital receipts has led to the launch of new businesses focused on digital receipt management. Analytics predict a steady decline in the popularity of traditional paperwork in the near future, as entrepreneurs now seem to almost completely switch to online document-management software.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==See also== {{Commons category|Bills and receipts}} * [[Bill of lading]] * [[Bill of materials]] * [[Certificate of origin]] * [[Delivery order]] * [[Document]] * [[Document automation]] * [[Invoice]] * [[Manifest (transportation)]] * [[Short shipment]] {{Wiktionary|receipt}} * [[Cash register]] * [[Depositary receipt]] * [[Document automation]] in supply chain management & logistics * [[List of finance topics]] * [[Point of sales]] * [[Proof of purchase]] * [[Return receipt]] * [[Electronic receipt]] (E-receipt)
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Accounting source documents]] [[Category:Paper products]]

(Rosemarie Yu) | business = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Russell Wendell M. Dionido ''' ({{zh|t={{linktext|楊|文|成}}|s={{linktext|杨|文|成}}|p=Yáng Wénchéng [[Pe̍h-ōe-jī]]:''Iûⁿ bûn-sêng''}}) was a [[Filipino Chinese]] businessman, financial, and insurance adviser.https://www.whowasborn.today/person/russell-wendell-morfe-dionido-ii%E6%A5%8A%E6%96%87%E6%88%90-1983-10-01/, retrieved 14 May 2018 a former activist and youth leader,he is one of the convenors in different youth alliances some of those are Education for All Movement-Quezon Chapter(E! 4all),Save Our Education Movement (Quezon Chapter),and Quezon Youth Speak(Q-Yspeak). now he writes some online publication regarding youth and students struggle and empowerment, he has been regular resource speaker of different forums, conferences and Conventions that tackle youth, education, and financial freedom. ==Early life== He was born at 9:00 am on October 1, 1983 at Daya Maternity Hospital in Gulang-Gulang, an urban district of City [[Lucena, Philippines|Lucena]]{{cite book|last1=|title=According to Mother|publisher=Rosemarie}} He was the eldest of two children born to Wendell Songco Dionido I (1958–2015), a Filipino Broadcast Journalist, and Rosemarie Mendoza Morfe, a businesswoman born as Rosemarie Mendoza Yu on January 31, 1960, a [[Filipino Chinese|Filipina with Chinese ancestry]] from the Yu (楊) family of [[Binondo]],[[Manila]] with ancestral ties to [[China]]'s [[Fujian province]],{{cite book|last1=|title=The Yu ,Mendoza,Morfe Family History|publisher=}} His younger sister named Nisreen born in June 12, 1985.{{cite book|last1=|title=The Family History|publisher=}} he was baptized according to the rites of ONE HOLY CATHOLIC APOSTOLIC CHURCH (Latin Rite) on April 15, 1984 by Rev.Fr. John B. Li (李文声神父) at the Holy Rosary Chapel, At the age of three his mother notice his willingness to enter to the world of business when the little Poochok ask her to buy him a rim of pad paper, and his mother ask him what he will do to the pad paper he immediately answer "itititinda ko po" (I will sell ), and at the age of four he wanted to sell "Taho" (a morning delicacy made from Soy beans) it is the very first ambition of Poochok to became an entrepreneur.{{cite book|last1=|title=According to Mother|publisher=Rosemarie}} ==Education== He completed his primary and secondary education in a school now known as [[Maryhill College]] (formerly Maryknoll Academy).{{cite book|last1=Maryhill College|title=The Arcade 2002|publisher=MC Batch 2001}} and earned his degree in [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Business Administration]], major in [[Management Accounting]]{{cite book|last1=Envega University|title=Maroon and White 2005-2006|publisher=The Luzonian 2006}} at [[Enverga University]]. in 2006. ==Business interests== ==Awards== Maryhill College honored him as first recipient of the Award of Distinction for School, Parish and Community Service 2002{{cite book|last1=Maryknollers Lucena|title=MC graduates 2002|publisher=Maryhill College}} The Supreme Council of Kappa Sigma Beta (KSB) honored Him as Jack of All Trades-Master of One for Leadership 2005{{cite book|last1=KSB|title=Kappa Sigma Beta (KSB) Jack of All Trades-Master of One|publisher=Kappa Sigma Beta Fraternity}} The Quezon Provincial Youth Parliament of Sanguniang Kabataan Provincial Federation awarded Him as Outstanding Youth Parliamentarian for the year 2006{{cite book|last1=4th PYP|title=SKPF-4thPYP|publisher=Sanguniang Kabataan Provincial Federation Quezon}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dionido, Russell Wendell Morfe}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Lucena, Philippines]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:Enverga University alumni]]

'''Salah Abdulla Nooruddin Nooruddin''' ({{lang-ar|صلاح عبد الله نور الدين نور الدين}}; born 1963) is [[Bahrain]]i [[Businessman]] and the former chairman of [[Leeds United Football Club]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23127891 | title=Leeds United: Salah Nooruddin becomes chairman | publisher=BBC | date=1 July 2013 | accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref><ref>http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/419605/Leeds-United-s-new-chairman-speaks-exclusively-to-the-Daily-Express</ref>
Bahraini-based businessman Salah Nooruddin, CEO of Envest Limited, initially bought a 3.33% stake in LUFC Holding Limited following the takeover of Leeds United by [[GFH Capital]]<nowiki> - an </nowiki>[[Islamic]] [[investment bank]] with headquarters in [[Bahrain]]. Nooruddin was initially appointed vice-chairman<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/leeds-united/latest-whites-news/salah-nooruddin-named-as-new-leeds-united-vice-chairman-1-5692630 | title=Salah Nooruddin named as new Leeds United vice-chairman | publisher=Yorkshire Evening Post | date=21 May 2013 | accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref> on 21 May 2013 but following the end of [[Ken Bates]]' tenure as chairman Nooruddin became chairman on 1 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.motforum.com/article.php?page=28998 | title=A good day for Leeds United | publisher=Marching on Together | date=1 July 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> It was later revealed that he had increased his stake in the club to 10%.
In early 2014 GFH Capital sold their majority stake in the club to Italian Businessman Massimo Cellino who then became majority shareholder by 75% this means GFH Capitol would only retain a 5% stake in the club while Nooruddin would retain a 10% stake through his company Envest Ltd while he would also look after the 10% stake in the club owned by the International Investment Bank.
In 2014 Nooruddin was removed as club chairman by new owner Massimo Cellino but would remain on the board of directors until April 2014 when he resigned from the board.
<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.motforum.com/article.php?page=29248 | title=The Takeover That Keeps on Giving | publisher=Marching on Together | date=15 August 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nooruddin, Salah}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chairmen of Leeds United F.C.]] [[Category:Bahraini businesspeople]]

{{Infobox company | name = Social Enterprise Association (SE Association) | logo = Seassociation logo.jpg | type = | genre = [[Voluntary association|Association]] | industry = [[Social Enterprises]]
[[Social Entrepreneur]] | foundation = 2009 | location_city = [[Singapore]] | location_country = [[Singapore]] | homepage = [http://www.seassociation.sg Official Website] }} The '''Social Enterprise Association''', also known as "SE Association", is a platform to bring together social entrepreneurs, social enterprises, academic institutions, and businesses in [[Singapore]].[http://app1.mcys.gov.sg/PressRoom/TheLaunchoftheSocialEnterpriseAssociation.aspx "The Launch of the Social Enterprise Association"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317013118/http://app1.mcys.gov.sg/PressRoom/TheLaunchoftheSocialEnterpriseAssociation.aspx |date=2012-03-17 }} The goal of the SE Association is to strengthen the culture of [[social entrepreneurship]] and [[social enterprise]]s so as to bring about positive [[social]] [[Social influence|impact]] within [[Singapore]]. This is done through:[http://seassociation.sg/downloads/Press%20Release-20%20Oct%202009-Launch%20of%20SEassociation.pdf "Press Release for Launch of SE Association - 20 Oct 09"]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} # Cultivating an environment which supports peer-learning within the social enterprise community # Organising [[capacity building]] programmes and business services # Fostering synergistic partnerships among key [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] (the Government, businesses and people) ==History== In August 2006, a Social Enterprise Committee chaired by Mr [[Philip Yeo]] was formed to explore growth opportunities within the local social enterprise sector.[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/315250/1/.html "Panel suggests more funding for social enterprises"] The 26 recommendations provided by the Committee included setting up a Social Enterprise Association and a Social Enterprise Development Centre to cultivate a thriving culture of [[social entrepreneurship]] and related enterprises. The Social Enterprise Implementation Committee chaired by [[Gerard Ee]] then carried out the relevant operational procedures to materialize the recommendations listed previously. In June 2009, the Association was officially registered as a [[Company Limited by Guarantee]]. Currently, SE Association is co-chaired by Mr Seah Kian Peng, CEO (Singapore) of [[NTUC Fairprice Co-operative]] Ltd, and Ms Penny Low, President and Founder of Social Innovation Park Ltd. The other two board members are Mr Alfie Othman, director of Ikhlas Holdings Pte Ltd, and Dr Gillian Koh, senior research fellow of the Institute of Policy Studies at [[Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy]] in the National University of Singapore. ==Community and membership== The SE Association's primary objective is to bring about positive social impact and an inclusive community among Singaporeans. It aims, first and foremost, to address the needs and interests of its target community – social enterprises, social entrepreneurs and would-be social innovators (see [[social innovation]]) – and then further engage other potential partners from the private sector and government to work on synergistic partnerships to promote the strength of its members and the sector as a whole. SE Association's members are social enterprises, individuals, students, voluntary welfare organisations / non-profit organisations, and corporate. Seminars, talks, [[focus groups]], consultations and networking sessions have been organized by the Association to provide learning opportunities for both members and the public. Their members are mostly located in the social enterprises in Singapore. ==Social Enterprise Development Centre (SEDC)== The SEDC belongs to the training and consultancy arm of SE Association. The SEDC was launched[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1088784/1/.html "Social Enterprise Development Center Launched"] in October 2010 to build up the institutional capacity of social enterprises by working alongside social entrepreneurs to nurture and develop their social enterprises from infancy to maturity, and thereafter integrate them with the mainstream business communities. SEDC offers two main advisory services: SE Start-up Advisory, and SE Business Advisory which includes advice and coaching. Advisory services offered without implementation plans is free- of- charge, but a fee is charged if SEDC is required to facilitate the development and execution of plans or where third party expertise is required. In addition, SEDC offers training and capability-building programmes for [[social enterprise]]s. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110222155625/http://www.seassociation.sg/ Official website] [[Category:Social entrepreneurship]] [[Category:Business organisations based in Singapore]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox video game |title = The Biz |image = TheBizTitleScreen.gif |caption = Title screen |developer = [[Virgin Group|Virgin Games]] |publisher = [[Virgin Group|Virgin Games]] |designer = [[Chris Sievey]]<ref name="worldofspectrum">{{cite web | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseekid.cgi?id=0000544| title = Designer/# of players information | publisher = [[World of Spectrum]]| date = | accessdate = 2011-03-21}}</ref> |released = {{vgrelease|EU|1984}} |genre = [[Simulation game|Simulation]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]]<ref name="worldofspectrum"/> |platform = [[ZX Spectrum]] }}
'''''The Biz''''' is a management simulation game published by [[Virgin Group|Virgin Games]] for the [[ZX Spectrum]] in 1984. In ''The Biz'', the player manages a [[rock music|rock]] band. The price of the game on release was £6.95, which is equivalent to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|6.95|1984|r=2}}}} today. The tape cassette contained the program, an interview with [[Frank Sidebottom]] and [[Chris Sievey]], and eight singles.<ref name="zxspectrumreviews"/>
==Gameplay== [[File:TheBizZXSpectrumScreenshot.jpg|250px|left|In this screeenshot, the player's father has won £40,000 while gambling on football. Unfortunately, the player only gets £10 as a way to keep the game balanced.]]
Players set up their rock band with [[Gig (musical performance)|gig]]s, make them [[rehearsal|rehearse]] new [[song]]s, and hire a [[recording studio]] for producing new [[album]]s. The player starts out with no talent or [[pound sterling|money]] and an [[talent agent|agent]] must be hired in order to better co-ordinate the band. The stage presence of the band and the [[fandom|fanbase]] are improved with every gig performed. School [[Dance party|dance]]s and [[YMCA]]s are the first places that accept the player's newly formed band. Real television stations are included: a band from either [[Swansea]] or [[Cardiff]] would perform on [[S4C]] while a local band from [[Coventry]] would get promoted on [[Central Independent Television|Central Television]]. Players can sometimes record a [[List of Peel sessions|session]] with [[John Peel]]; whose broadcasting influence opened up new bands to people between the ages of 20 and 60 years of age.
Mundane details such as [[insurance]], standard [[musical instrument]]s and transportation [[expense]]s are all tabulated against the player's savings in the game. The game also contains an anti-[[drug]] message for bands who consider experimenting with them.
==Reviews== The game only contains sound effects and no music, although eight singles were included on the cassette. There are no graphics to speak of and the game is [[text-based game|text-based]]. A [[Crash (magazine)|Crash]] review in March 1985 praised the game, stating that it was ''"[a]n unusually absorbing and addictive strategy/simulation with a sense of humour that represents good value."''<ref name="zxspectrumreviews">{{cite web | url = http://www.zxspectrumreviews.co.uk/Review.aspx?rid=5429&gid=661| title = Criticism of game | publisher = ZX Spectrum Reviews| date = | accessdate = 2011-03-21}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{refimprove|date=April 2015}} {{infobox |title = Toronto Global Forum | abovestyle = | above = |imagestyle = |captionstyle = | image = [[File:Toronto Global Forum Logo.png|center]] | caption = | headerstyle = | header1 = | label1 = Organized by | data1 = [[International Economic Forum of the Americas]] | header2 = | label2 = Type | data2 = International Conference | header3 = | label3 = Frequency | data3 = Annually | header4 = | label4 = Founded | data4 = 2007 | header5 = | label5 = Founded by | data5 = [[Nicholas Rémillard]] | header6 = | label6 = Location | data6 = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] | header7 = | label7 = Topics | data7 = {{plainlist| *[[Finance]] *[[Trade]] *[[Innovation]] *[[Energy]] *[[Infrastructure]] *[[Commodities]] }} | header8 = | label8 = Next Event | data8 = December 10 - 12, 2018 | header9 = | label9 = Sister Organizations | data9 = {{plainlist| *[[Conference of Montreal]] *[[World Strategic Forum]]}} | header10 = | label10 = Website | data10 = {{URL|http://forum-americas.org/toronto}}}}
The '''Toronto Global Forum''' (TGF) is an annual economic event organized by the [[International Economic Forum of the Americas]] since 2007.
==Mission== The Toronto Global Forum is a [[not-for-profit organization]] presenting annual conferences on global economic issues. The TGF mission is to promote open debate and dialogues on national and international issues. Each year, the event welcomes heads of state, Fortune 500 CEOs, international organizations, central bank governors, civil society, etc. to foster free discussion between world leaders.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arizona Teachers Inspire A Love Of Learning|url=http://yumanewsnow.com/index.php/news/latest/1236-governor-brewer-to-address-business-ceos-at-toronto-global-forum|website=yumanewsnow.com|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=en-gb}}</ref> The forum brings together more than 2,800 people from across the globe every year.<ref>https://www.hilltimes.com/politics-this-morning/2015/07/08/politics-this-morning-toronto-global-forum-getsundeway/42757{{Deadlink|date=March 2017}}</ref>
The forum also provide a platform to facilitate meetings between key world leaders in order to encourage global discourse.
The International Economic Forum of the Americas hosts two other annual events: the [[Conference of Montreal]] (founded in 1995), as well as the [[World Strategic Forum]], held in Miami (founded in 2011).<ref>Ostrowski, Jeff. "Strategic Forum ends four-year run in county". The Palm Beach Post [Palm Beach] April 9, 2014 p.B6</ref>
{{-}} ==Notable speakers== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Navdeep Bains]], Canadian [[Minister of Innovation, Science and Economic Development]]<ref name=nbio>[http://feia.forum-americas.org/profile/navdeep-bains]</ref> *[[Dominic Barton]], global managing director, [[McKinsey & Company]]<ref name=asiancenturyinstitute>[http://asiancenturyinstitute.com/economy/924-2015-toronto-global-forum-july-8-10 Asian Century Institute]</ref> *[[Mark Carney]], Governor, [[Bank of England]] *[[Ian Bremmer]], President and Founder, Eurasia Group; and Editor-at-Large, TIME Magazine *[[Dick Cheney]], [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States|Vice President of the United States of America]] (2001-2009)<ref>{{cite news|title=Something's Gone Terribly Wrong|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/29/dick-cheney-canadaarrest_|accessdate=19 March 2017|publisher=[[The Huffington Post]]}}</ref> *Christophe Frei, Secretary-General,[[World Energy Council]] (WEC) *[[Shuman Ghosemajumder]], former click fraud czar, [[Google]]<ref name=sbio>[https://feia.forum-americas.org/profile/shuman-ghosemajumder]</ref> *[[Moya Greene]], CEO, [[Royal Mail]]<ref name=s2017list>[http://forum-americas.org/toronto/2017-edition/speakers/]</ref> *[[Alan Greenspan]], 13th Chairman, [[Federal Reserve Bank]] of the United States (1987-2006) *[[José Ángel Gurría]], secretary-general, [[OECD]]<ref name=s2017list></ref> *Douglas M. Hodge, chief executive officer, [[PIMCO]]<ref name=asiancenturyinstitute /> *Joseph L. Hooley, chairman and chief executive officer, [[State Street Corporation]]<ref name=asiancenturyinstitute /> *[[Josu Jon Imaz]], Chief Executive Officer [[Repsol]] *[[Daniel Johnston]], [[Governor General of Canada]]<ref name=asiancenturyinstitute /> *[[Jim Yong Kim]], President, [[The World Bank]] *[[Henry Kissinger]], [[List of Secretaries of State of the United States|Secretary of State]] of the United States (1973-1977)<ref name=Financialpost>[http://business.financialpost.com/2014/11/01/henry-kissingers-new-world-order/ Financial Post]</ref> *[[Isabelle Kocher]], Chief Executive Officer, [[ENGIE]] *[[Christine Lagarde]], Managing Director, [[International Monetary Fund]] *[[Haruhiko Kuroda]], 31st Governor, [[Bank of Japan]] *[[Joanne Liu]], International President, Doctor Without Borders ([[Médecins Sans Frontières|MSF]]) *[[Luis Alberto Moreno]], President, [[Inter-American Development Bank]] *[[Lucas Papademos]], [[List of Prime Ministers of Greece|Prime Minister of Greece]] (2011-2012), former governor of [[Bank of Greece|Central Bank of Greece]], and former vice-president of the [[European Central Bank]] *[[Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera]], [[List of Presidents of Costa Rica|President of the Republic of Costa Rica]] *[[Joseph Stiglitz]], [[List of Nobel Memorial Prize laureates in Economics|Nobel Memorial Prize laureate in Economics]] *Paul Taylor, president and chief executive officer, [[Fitch Ratings]] *[[Robert James Thomson]], chief executive, [[News Corp]] *[[Jean-Claude Trichet]], former president, [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) *[[German Vargas Lleras]], [[Vice President of Colombia]] (2014-2017) *Donald J. Walker, chief executive officer, [[Magna International]] *[[Martin Wolf]], chief economics commentator, ''[[Financial Times]]'' *[[Fareed Zakaria]], host, [[CNN]]'s [[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]<ref name=Financialpost /> }}
==Advisory board==
=== '''Chairman''' ===
* [[John M. Beck]], [[Aecon Group Inc.]]
===Members=== Current members of the advisory board of the Toronto Global Forum are:
*[[Dominic Barton]], Global Managing Director, McKinsey & Company Show *Laurence Batlle, Chief Executive Officer, [[RATP Dev]] *Christiane Bergevin, President, Bergevin Capital and Chair of the Board, Canadian Chamber of Commerce *Janet De Silva, [[Toronto Region Board of Trade]] *Benoit Parent, Vice-President, Power Generation Business and Nuclear Operations, Cummins Sales and Service *Nicholas Rémillard, President and Chief Executive Officer, [[International Economic Forum of the Americas]] *[[Gregory Smith (investment manager)|Gregory Smith]], President and Chief Executive Officer, [[AGF Management|InstarAGF Asset Management]]; and Executive Chairman Nieuport Aviation Infrastructure Partners *Kenneth Tanenbaum, Chairman, Kilmer Developments; and Vice-Chairman Kilmer Van Nostrand (KVN) *[[Michael Thompson (Canadian politician)|Michael Thompson]], Councillor and Chair, Economic Development and Culture Committee, [[City of Toronto]]; and Chair, Invest Toronto *[[Geoffrey A. Wilson]], President and Chief Executive Officer, [[PortsToronto]] *[[Michael Wilson (Canadian politician)|Michael Wilson]], Chairman [[Barclays Capital]]; Former [[Finance Minister|Minister of Finance of Canada]], Canada; and Former [[List of Canadian ambassadors to the United States|Canadian Ambassador to the United States]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Advisory Board of International Economic Forum of the Americas |url=http://forum-americas.org/toronto/advisory-board |accessdate=19 March 2017 |publisher=Forum-americas.org |language=en |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161124093702/http://forum-americas.org/toronto/advisory-board |archivedate=24 November 2016 }}</ref> *[[Paul Zed]], Secretary to the Toronto Global Forum Advisory Board

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} '''Val Irvine McCalla''' (3 October 1943 – 22 August 2002) was a Jamaican accountant and media entrepreneur who settled in Britain in 1959. He is best known as the founder of [[The Voice (newspaper)|''The Voice'']], a [[United Kingdom|British]] weekly newspaper aimed at the Britain's black community, which he established in 1982 as a voice for the [[British African-Caribbean community]]. He was honoured as a pioneering publisher for the community, but also faced critics who deemed him sensationalistic.<ref>{{cite news| title = Memorial tributes to Voice founder| publisher = [[BBC News]]| date =3 October 2002| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/2293867.stm | accessdate =23 May 2009}}</ref>
In the 100 Great Black Britons poll conducted in 1997, Val McCalla was voted number 68.<ref>[http://100greatblackbritons.com/results.htm "100 Great Black Britons".]</ref>
==Biography== Val McCalla was born in a poor part of [[Kingston, Jamaica]].<ref>Andy Beckett, [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/the-voice-in-the-wilderness-1318359.html "The Voice in the Wilderness"], ''The Independent'', 11 February 1996.</ref> After studying accountancy at [[Kingston College (Jamaica)|Kingston College]], a Jamaican high school, McCalla travelled to England in May 1959, aged 15. He joined the [[RAF]], but a perforated eardrum put paid to his dreams of becoming a pilot and instead he honed his skills as a bookkeeper,<ref name=EB>[https://www.britannica.com/biography/Val-McCalla "Val McCalla"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica''.</ref> leaving in the mid-1960s.<ref>Steve Pope, [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/aug/24/guardianobituaries.raceandreligion "Val McCalla"] (obituary), ''[[The Guardian]]'', 24 August 2002.</ref> He then found employment in various accounts and book-keeping positions, before working part-time on a community newspaper, ''East End News'', based near his flat in [[Bethnal Green]].<ref>[http://www.100greatblackbritons.com/bios/val_mccalla.html "Val McCalla"], 100 Great Black Britons.</ref> He started ''The Voice'' newspaper in 1982, with a team that included broadcaster [[Alex Pascall]],<ref>[[Andy Beckett]], [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/the-voice-in-the-wilderness-1318359.html "The Voice in the Wilderness"], ''The Independent'', 11 February 1996.</ref><ref>[[Lionel Morrison]], [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=76M-nuHaji8C&pg=PA63&lpg=PA63&dq=alex+pascall+%22the+voice%22&source=bl&ots=zgoz9jxUx6&sig=DW3OOTDwnDKMFYaQlkNSdiTLTBQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxx4GAurXXAhUrLsAKHW7rCTYQ6AEIbzAP#v=onepage&q=alex%20pascall%20%22the%20voice%22&f=false ''A Century of Black Journalism in Britain: A Kaleidoscopic View of Race and the Media (1893–2003)''], Truebay Limited, 2007, p. 63.</ref> launching it at the [[Notting Hill carnival]] that August,<ref>George Ruddock, [http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/voice35years-happy-birthday-us "Voice35Years: Happy Birthday To Us!"], ''The Voice'', 27 August 2017.</ref> and bringing in Viv Broughton as marketing manager.<ref>Steve Alexander Smith, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3uUe0B0Z9noC&pg=PT39&lpg=PT39&dq=val+mccalla+viv+broughton&source=bl&ots=CP6S8GGYOH&sig=uJ1ck5v68ygkVGSnr3edKQD37v0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi22NqLgLXXAhWCT7wKHa-gA28Q6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=val%20mccalla%20viv%20broughton&f=false "Viv Broughton"], ''British Black Gospel: The Foundations of this Vibrant UK Sound'', Monarch Books, 2009, p. 78.</ref>
McCalla died of [[liver failure]] on 22 August 2002, aged 58, in [[Seaford, East Sussex]], where he was buried.<ref>Angelique Chrisafis, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/aug/24/arts.raceandreligion "McCalla, publisher who gave black people a voice, dies"], ''The Guardian'', 24 August 2002.</ref><ref name=EB /><ref>[http://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/news/parish-church-packed-for-funeral-of-black-newspaper-s-founder-1-959647 "Parish church packed for funeral of black newspaper's founder"], ''Sussex Express'', 5 September 2002.</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://www.britannica.com/biography/Val-McCalla "Val McCalla"], ''Encyclopædia Britannica'' * Steve Pope, [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/aug/24/guardianobituaries.raceandreligion "Val McCalla"] (obituary), ''[[The Guardian]]'', 24 August 2002. * [http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/we-remember-val-mccalla-founder-voice "We Remember Val McCalla, Founder Of 'The Voice'"], ''The Voice'', 22 August 2017.

''[[Business Edition]]'' | website = http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/n13xtmdv | website_title = ''World Business Report'' }} '''''World Business Report''''' is a television [[business]] news programme produced by [[BBC News]] and shown on [[BBC World News]] and the [[BBC News (TV channel)|BBC News]] channel on weekdays. The programme is broadcast 10 times daily Monday - Fridays. The main presenters of the programme are [[Tanya Beckett]], [[Sally Bundock]], Sally Eden, [[Juliette Foster]], Alice Baxter, [[Aaron Heslehurst]], Jamie Robertson and Philip Hampsheir. [[Sara Coburn]], [[Maryam Moshiri]] and [[Nancy Kacungira]] act as relief presenters. It was first broadcast in 1995. ==Previous presenters== *[[Darshini David]] *[[Paddy O'Connell]] *[[Manisha Tank]] *[[Owen Thomas (journalist)|Owen Thomas]] ==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/1143010.stm BBC World Business Report] * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2102246/combined BBC World Business Report at IMDB.com] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zhds93M7j4k/ World Business Report promo in 1995] {{Portal|BBC}} {{BBC News}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} [[Category:1995 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:1990s British television series]] [[Category:2000s British television series]] [[Category:2010s British television series]] [[Category:BBC television news programmes]] [[Category:BBC World News programmes]] [[Category:Business-related television series]] [[Category:British television news programmes]] {{BBC-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Yasser Elshantaf
{{small|ياسر الشنتف}} | image = Yasser Elshantaf.jpg | caption = German-Palestinian Entrepreneur | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|01|20}} | birth_place = [[Al-Shati Camp]], [[Gaza Strip]] | nationality = [[Germany|German]], [[Palestinian People|Palestinian origin]] | spouse = Maram Elshantaf | occupation = [[CEO]] of PhoenixBird Diversity Management GmbH [http://pb-dm.de/yasser-elshantaf''Yasser Elshantaf: Phoenixbird Diversity Management GmbH''] | residence = [[Berlin, Germany]] | website = {{Facebook|Yasser.Elshantaf}} }} '''Yasser Elshantaf''' ({{lang-ar|ياسر الشنتف }}, {{transl|ar|Yāsir Elshāntāf}}; born January 20, 1983) is a [[Germany|German]] entrepreneur of [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] origin and co-founder and CEO of PhoenixBird Diversity Management GmbH.{{YouTube|id=ncxOrnJ3xI4|title="Yasser Elshantaf, Documentary has been released on Alghad TV“}} ==Early life and education== Yasser Elshantaf {{cite web |url=http://www.all4palestine.com/ModelDetails.aspx?gid=8&mid=5287&lang=en|title= Yasser Elshantaf, Businessman |work= All 4 Palestine}}{{cite web |url=http://dw.com/p/1DZXZ|title= Yasser Elshantaf, european bank stress test.|work= Made in Germany - The Business Magazine, Deutsche Welle |date=22 October 2014}} was born in [[Al-Shati camp]] in [[Gaza Strip]]. His parents became refugees after they fled their homes in [[Jaffa]] during the 1948 [[Arab-Israeli War]]. He studied [[computer information systems]], [[political science]] and [[crisis management]]. In 2009, he traveled to [[Germany]] after winning the [[Konrad Zuse Scholarship Programme 2009|Konrad-Zuse-Program]] as an [[entrepreneur]]. The prize was presented by the [[German Foreign Office]], and focuses on [[research and development]] in the [[information technology]] field. ==Career== {{rquote|left|The Palestinian private sector not looking for donation, it’s looking for real business partners.|Yasser Elshantaf, 2009}} Elshantaf started his career in Palestine as [[IT consultant]] and served in various capacities in the field of [[organizational development]] and [[strategy]]. Since 2004, he carried out consulting projects for the [[World Bank]], [[European Union]], and the [[American Friends Service Committee]]. He is currently Managing Partner & [[CEO]] of PhoenixBird Diversity Management GmbH in [[Berlin]], and also [[Co-founder]] of PhoenixBird Information Technology and Systems L.T.D.{{cite web |url= http://www.phoenixbird.eu/yasser-elshantaf |title= Yasser Elshantaf, Chairman|work= PhoenixBird Information Technology & Systems L.T.D.}} [[File:Yasser Elshantaf 05.jpg|thumb|left|The International Symposium on [[Cultural Diplomacy]] 2011, [[Hard power|Hard]] Vs. [[Soft Power]] in Global and National Politics]] On 29 January 2014, Elshantaf talked to [[Deutsche Welle]] {{cite news |url= http://p.dw.com/p/1Ayja |title= Yasser Elshantaf, challenges facing the German private sector |work= Made in Germany - The Business Magazine, Deutsche Welle |date=29 January 2014}} about the public concern over [[China]]'s growing [[economic power]], classification criteria for leading companies, and challenges facing the German private sector. On 29 and 30 March 2012, Elshantaf was invited by the German Foundation for International Legal Cooperation and Center for International Peace Operations to a workshop under the title of Corruption and Compliance in [[Transition countries|Transition Countries]] in [[North Africa]] to talk about [[strategies]] and best practices for international legal cooperation in the fight against corruption in transitional societies. Elshantaf participated in the 12th German-Arab Business Forum,{{cite web |url= http://www.dpw-ev.de/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=174:guttenberg&catid=47:aktuell&lang=de&Itemid=0|title= German-Arab Economic Forum: Yasser Elshantaf, Co-founder and secretary-general |work= DPW e.V. | date= 6 November 2009}} which was held in cooperation between the Arab-German [[Chamber of Commerce]] and the [[Chamber of Commerce and Industry|German Chamber of Commerce and Industry]].He presented a lecture under the title "[[Information and communication technologies|ICT]], the future for Palestine". Elshantaf is a [[Entrepreneur|co-founder]] of the German-Palestinian Business Council DPW e.V.; a member of the International Non-Profit Business Association for CEOs and Entrepreneurs, the [[Junior Chamber International]], [[Chamber of Commerce and Industry]] of [[Berlin]], and the Palestinian Information Technology Association. He has also been involved in many activities supporting the community and the [[Palestinian economy]]. == Political views == Elshantaf is [[liberalism|liberal]] and a [[democracy|democrat]] who believes peace has to be made between people, rather than between governments. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category}} {{wikiquote}} ==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ncxOrnJ3xI4&feature=youtu.be Yasser Elshantaf, Diaspora documentary] Alghad TV, 07 April 2018 *[http://p.dw.com/p/2ndEb Yasser Elshantaf, How affecting the new employment law for workers coming from Eastern Europe] Deutsche Welle, Made in Germany - The Business Magazine, 15 November 2017 *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j85XMTmCfbM&feature=youtu.be Yasser Elshantaf, Innovative ideas] Deutsche Welle, Shabab Talk, 03 September 2014 *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gBY4bABmxxg&feature=youtu.be Immigration to Germany] Deutsche Welle, Shabab Talk, 22 January 2014 *[http://www.mobaderoon.ps/ar/mag/Mobaderoon_magazine_Vol1.pdf Yasser Elshantaf, Mobaderoon Entrepreneur Magazine] in Gaza, 2013 *[http://www.zif-berlin.org/fileadmin/uploads/training/dokumente/Agenda_Korruptionsbekaempfung_und_Compliance_in_Nordafrika_03.2012.pdf Strategies and best practices for international legal cooperation in the fight against corruption, Center for International Peace Operations] in Berlin, 30 March 2012 *[https://www.alwatanvoice.com/arabic/news/2009/03/24/136258.html Yasser Elshantaf, Konrad Zuse Scholarship Programme] Donia Al-Watan, 2009 *[http://unctad.org/sections/about/docs/osgcioinf20091_en.pdf Public Symposium, Geneva 2009. United Nations Conference on Trade and Development] in Geneva, 12 August 2009 *[http://www.ldf.ps/documentsShow.aspx?ATT_ID=2182 PED Project, An Assessment of the Outsourcing Capabilities of the Palestinian ICT Industry] April 21 - May 3, 2008 *[http://www.ceoclubs.org/section/biographies/entrepreneurial/elshantaf.htm Yasser Elshantaf, the CEO Clubs International] {{DEFAULTSORT:Elshantaf, Yasser}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Gaza Governorate]] [[Category:Palestinian businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Berlin]]
